4I85eHZZKO7QV9ZU7ZSA7Q.text: Very unique place with high quality food. I had the pork rolls and the beef noodle soup. The rolls had a juicy marinated pork with very little fat.  The beef noodle soup also had really good meat, which is a rarity for that dish.  My wife loves all the dishes she picked too -all authentic Taiwanese brunch food.  I wish it was open past 3pm.

VNm9rG6CLhl3RIhIXZBIgg.text: Sure, I love their one-of-a-kind salty soy milk and egg-wrapped fried bread, but what struck me are the values that the deli owners & employees strive to uphold. A sign in Chinese read the following:   "However frustrated you are, don't forget to smile. However impatient you are, don't forget to be polite. However difficult, don't forget to persevere. However tired you are, don't forget to take care of yourself."  Restaurants often deliver great food, but never have I been to one that has also delivered words of wisdom. Thanks for the reminder, Yi Mei Deli!

VI_j7KyJvZbNUTktvzIdeA.text: Great chinese food.  They got a little bit of everything.  I come here mainly for the Chinese Breakfast.  Like Chinese Donut, great onion pancake, beef wraps, rice wraps, etc.  The beef noodle soup is also really good.  Got to check it out.

WeKDjgCz1BTduMNdFIHFOA.text: Located at the corner of S. Jones and Spring Mountain near the 168 Market, this small humble eatery provides a comprehensive array of Taiwanese breakfast items that elicit childhood nostalgia for many 1st generation Taiwanese/Chinese folks and are definitely on the must-eat list for those of us second-generation folks who have been fortunate to have made a pilgrimmage back to Taiwan (or as I like to call it, Foodie Island).    Soybean milk-  this is not the chalky stuff that you find in your supermarket that adds a nice dimension to your latte or cereal, this is enjoyed straight up either as a sweetened cold/hot beverage or in a savory form where a shot of vinegar and soy triggers a reaction so that the soymilk takes on a creamy custardization accented by little bits of green onion and pickled veggies.  For those with discernible palates, I've been informed by reputable sources that the soybean milk across the street at China Mama is superior.  Rice Ball (Fan Twan)- a classic item my parents used to grab on the go while heading to school, don't be fooled by the simple name.  This is steamed sticky rice enclosing a savory deep fried chinese doughnut and pork sung.  The ratio of the rice and filling is perfect and it's as classic a combination as pb and j.  Temple meatball (Ba Wan)-  not sure if there are any other places in town that offer this, and fortunately they make a wonderful version of this popular street food item.    Finely chopped mushrooms, bamboo, and stir-fried pork encased by a glutinous tapioca flour bun and bathed in a thick orange sweet savory sauce that has an additional note similar to cinnamon/star anise, this one will flood your head with umami and makes me think if boba and dim sum were to conceive a rockstar child, this would be it.  Spicy Beef Noodle soup-   Served piping hot and can easily feed 2 or more, the meat is impeccably braised and comes with garnishes of pickled mustard greens, cilantro, scallions, and bok choy.  Detractors might say it is on the oily side and is way spicy (in which case the version at Noodle Pot may be closer to your liking), otherwise this one punches you in the face and is not shy on flavor in the best way possible.  Leek Pancake- A deep-fried empanada filled with garlic chives, scrambled egg, tofu, and mung bean noodles, this is a tasty rendition if you really like garlic chives.  Items that have room for improvement include the savory chinese doughnuts (yiotiao) and the sesame bun (sao bing) which I found to be a tad bit on the dry side, and the hunk of pork in the pork bun (gua bao) is also a bit oversized and lacking unctuousness (Sheridan Su does a better rendition at Great Bao which is now Fat Choy).  Looking forward to trying the pork chop with rice, sweet tofu custard (do hua), and the lotus wrapped tamales (taiwanese and shanghainese varieties available) on future visits.   Not sure if this is an outpost of Yi Mei Deli Co. in Rowland Heights, CA (the fonts on the food signs look similar), but if you're expecting the same level of quality, it may come up short since they set the bar extremely high, otherwise it's a great primer on Taiwanese cuisine for the uninitiated.  Unbelievable value for your wallet but don't forget cash if you're spending under $10 and they accept visa/mastercard but no amex.

u-GjQS1ZSEcmKrkqbQDekQ.text: I only wish that I could rate this place less than a star. We arrived for breakfast around 8:00 AM and stood around for over 20 minutes completely ignored. They had 5 open tables. I asked the staff multiple times if we could sit at a table or place an order and was rudely waved off each time. After about half an hour of being ignored we left. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME AT THIS ESTABLISHMENT!!!

BxtRXOXDEoHyehBAIY5agA.text: We went to this place in the morning and it was semi-busy.  We were ignored by the owner lady and her husband who was busing the tables.   No menu were offered nor host taking us to the seat.  Some other patrons told us that we can  seat ourselves..Once we sat, we saw other trying to take menu off the cash register after 15 min wait and she served others holding the menus first.  I asked her if there is a problem with the shortage on staff and she told me that she sent many to the casinos out for delivery so she couldn't make the food fast enough and everyone else was waiting..You will have to wait until all after all these people are served.  We WALKED OUT..  She does NOT CARE..and I KNEW she is the OWNER..WILL NOT RETURN

vyVNeehyOwdJmLpp65PPdA.text: Perfect Chinese food. Really, regardless of the Yelp rating which is mainly resulted from their tricks in billing, have to say the food is excellent. And it is not expensive at all.   ,

-hXaQT-8jqBiC7KyHiFcqQ.text: Lawrence C. must be talking about the Korean joint next door to Yi Mei cause the beef noodle soup here is as good as it gets. I came here with my family and the meal was absolutely delicious (and to Emily R: the menu is just fine; items are understandable; there are just some things that are lost in translation).   The beef noodle soup was full of beef. Not only that, but this beef was so deliciously tender. The noodles were infinitely better than Lawrence described... The soup was very lite, and not oily like many beef noodle soups that I've had before; the noodles weren't overcooked or undercooked. For an appetizer, I ordered the beef  tendon and that was very flavorful (I ordered it spicy) and was a pretty large order for the $2.50 that we paid for it. We also ordered a handful of other items off the menu like shao bing, fan tuan, soy milk, and a few other pastries and they all were excellent for the price. Everything was flavorful, but not overwhelmingly so at any point. The soy milk they serve plain so you're able to add sugar to your liking (just like in Taiwan!). No corn syrup crap here.  I would come here over and over again if I lived in the area but alas, it's an 8+ hr drive from where I live :(  Don't know if any claims on Yelp mean anything, but my family is Taiwanese too and we enjoyed the meal so that might mean something...?

We ordered spicy beef soup, xiao long bao, soy milk, green onion pancake, jook with Chinese donut (soft fluffy), steamed bun and sausage. It cost us $35 for all that food. My favorite was xiao long bao. These Taiwanese people know how to make it juicy and soft.   One of mid age lady (staff) came around each table and gave a package of senbei to each child. What a nice and surprising customer service. She's like a Santa.

Someone took our orders but never asked us if we need something to drink. It wasn't busy at all by the time we came. We asked for 3 Glases of water but the server only brought us two after a while. 0Z_6nEgGFW_5Idl0WHrNmw.text: Not many Chinese/Taiwanese breakfast places are Open early and I was in the mood for a traditional breakfast this morning.  You know, I feel bummed whenever I fly into Vegas earlier than 8am because unlike the San Gabriel Valley in SoCal, I struggle to find places to eat a traditional HK style or Taiwanese style breakfast.  Why is it so?  There are so many of our people here now..... Then I came across this neat restaurant in the heart of Chinatown that satisfied my need.  They have hot soy milk, plain steamed porridge, pancakes of most variety, Chinese donut and meat rolls.  The kinds of stuff I was looking for and the prices are more than reasonable.   Now off to the gym then business....

ulrhphZzp9rFGrY0B0ZooQ.text: Came here for some traditional Taiwanese breakfast. We ordered the soy milk, salted rice roll, omelet wrapped fried dough stick, and an oyster pancake. Everything was delicious, but I probably would order the oyster pancake again. It was 8 dollars and I thought it was just okay, I wish the batter was a bit slimier like how they are at the night markets. Overall a great choice for breakfast while in vegas

QsUTGIOOha8KesL8p6VwXw.text: Dim sum in Vegas, am I right?  But maybe you're a little spooked by other places that have long waits or lousy reputations on yelp. Well open your mind to a slightly different experience: tawainese breakfast! It's slightly different than dim sum but not so different that you'll be confused. There's XLB, there's bao, there's chinese doughnuts, there's all kinds of spicy nom noms, there's something for everyone! Seriously!  We came here on a Sunday morning, hungry. We left the opposite of hungry. The service was friendly if a little slow to get started. We liked the ample parking and the fact that a Chinese tour group showed up right after we did (they ate their breakfast like champions - truly impressive intake) and that we were the only native English speakers there.  Most importantly we liked the food and appreciated the good advice we got from our server. And the bill was reasonable too. :)  Enjoy life. Regret nothing. Eat at Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli. You'll be the champion when you do.

uRnJxv991gQAcr-vCZjlBA.text: Seasoned duck necks are ideal appetizer. Salty and sweet soy bean milk are warm and suitable to the cold weather. The XIAOLONG bun is my favorite even tho the chef is from TAIWAN. Never miss The TAIWAN Sausage! No ideas on the breakfast or brunch? Come here!

qpIBJSjYJPHdRkBYksgZdg.text: We ordered soybean curd and Chinese pancake with egg, they were pretty good, very friendly owner and nice service. Btw, you need to pay cash if below20$.

CDImWkmOhel9eB8tmYj24g.text: Any visit to Las Vegas always includes a trip to Yi Mei since I was introduced to this place. The restaurant is owned by Taiwanese owners, serving authentic Taiwanese food. My favorite dish: Egg Pancake.  This past visit, we ordered almost one of everything on the menu, so I might miss a few descriptions of some of the food items.  Both steamed and pan fried pork dumplings were served with a sweet ginger vinegar sauce. The dumplings were juicy and full of flavour. These dishes tasted amazing.  There were a few other pan fried dishes, but my favourite was the egg pancake and oyster pancake. The egg pancake had a layer of pan fried egg on top of a green onion pancake. The flavors just mesh so well together. The oyster pancake was thin and chewy just as it is supposed to be. The sauce for the oyster pancake is hard to master, but complimented the pancake so well.   Overall, I recommend making time to try this restaurant. Since most of the food is carb-y, it is also great for breakfast the morning after drinking. I would recommend any dish in the menu, and you won't be disappointed.

LWWeNa2i5j4zKi193Mf2HA.text: Beware. This place has good food most of the time but the service there has always been terrible. They definitely don't deserve to be tipped. Now they started charging gratuity for everything including even if only one  person. If they want a tip then provide service don't charge someone for providing bad service. Will not be returning. To many others places that serves good food as well as provide outstanding  service.

rS0EonxfquIsm3cXwxunHg.text: ***** Worst Beef Noodle Soup *****   The instant beef noodle soup (Nissin- I believe) is better.  Seriously, go put that in the microwave and it'll be better.  And trust me, I am a snob.  I grew up in a town with alot of Taiwanese people.  I'll give it 2 stars because the niu rou xiao bing (don't know the english name) but it' s like a flaky pastry with beef inside is good.    There's some decent stuff here and I guess since there's not a plethora of Taiwanese options, I can see why people are reviewing higher.

_GPYlHFwPSIz1VKmZ-SjYQ.text: My wife and I are foodies and having relocated from HK to here we are in constant search of all of our "favorites" from asia.  Being that we would take food vacations to taipei we walked into Yi Mei with some trepidation.  Now before I continue on, I do want to mention that HK is not actually a great place for taiwanese food (or else we wouldnt go on foodie trips to taipei).  We ordered the spicy beef noodle soup.  Had a little bit of heat but not sweating sort of spicy.  Which was great because it had a great taste that would've been covered up had it been too spicy.  Very nice!  It was also quite big, I am used to the little paper bowls of beef noodle soup in the alleyways of taiwan, not the american sized portions.  Couldnt finish it all and the waitress (the owners grand daughter) was great and brought me 2 containers 1 for the soup the other for the noodles so it wouldnt go all soggy together.    My wife ordered the steamed pork rice.  I knew it was good as soon as she declared "I'm not sharing!"  Of course she did and it was very good we were impressed.   My wife had the cold soy milk and enjoyed it I ordered the hot and had to put sugar in it, home made and nice. everything was home made and it was like having a personal taiwanese grandma cooking for us.  Then onto the Xiao Lum Bao.  the filling was good the skin a little thick and not enough "soup" inside the dumpling.  These took awhile but they were by far the best I have had in the USA.  Din Tai Fun sets a very high bar,we have gone to the DTF in taipei, shenzen, hong kong, singapore and jakarta (no pork at DTF in jakarta no pork dumplings suck).  Great food, nice family atmosphere place.  We will be going back anytime we plan on going to the 168 market for shopping.

YaHSV1bZ11w1fjBnorEJGg.text: Hooray, they were open on Chrstmas day!  Thank goodness I can count  Chinese to be working on the holidays!  Came in for a quick bite before my flight.  I got there around 8 am and the place was relatively empty.  I knew I had lucked out since that would not last.  The waitress handed me a menu and told me there would be no noodles until later in the day.  Good, since that means they are making it fresh, bad since I was craving some noodles.  Oh well.  I ordered the sweet soy milk (x2), steamed soup dumplings, onion pancake with egg, and a beef roll.  Everything came out rather quickly, that was good since I was on a time crunch.  The sweet soy milk was actually unsweetened and warm.  There was sugar on the table so I was able to sweeten it to my liking.  There was also a thin film on top, according to my mom, it is similar to tofu, very authentic, and the best part.  The steamed soup dumplings were good, the skins were a little thick this morning and they could have served it with more ginger.  The beef roll had lots of oninons and hoisin sauce and the pancake it came warpped in wasn't too thick.  The most lacking dish was the onion pancake.  It was very bland, I think the egg made it more so, to the point I sprinkled salt on it.  There weren't a lot of onions in it and instead of being crispy on the outside, it was soft throughout.  Service was efficient, and no one seemed grouchy for having to work on Christmas day.  And the staff spoke my dialect of Chinese, without any heavy accent, just like being in Taipei.  The entire bill for all my food was less than $20, a definite bargain.  Overall, a great place to eat and be reminded of home.

FB6K5JhMYnR5kD2Qk0MCog.text: The one person staff was friendly but that is all the positive that i can say about it.    We had the hot soybean milk and it was the worst we have ever tried.  They did not filter the soybeans out of it and there was grinded up soybean gunk and slime in our bowls and it clung to our spoons.  The aftertaste was even worse.    The selections for other breakfast foods were not as expected for chinese breakfast places.  We wanted a single order of red bean bun, and found out that we had to order a min of 6 at $5.99 total.  Glad we did not order that b/c if it tasted anything like the soybean milk, we would have been highly disappointed.    we will not be going back.

9-n-31kN7-EK4A5ONSzMpQ.text: My Taiwanese friends love this place since they can get their basic breakfast here for cheap. However, the few times I've been here the place is so crowded that if you're JUST ONE PERSON, you'll never sit down and enjoy your food!   Both times I came here they overlooked me for a larger group. Once I was sat, they moved me to share a different table with another small group.   The food is ok but it's not the gem in the rough I was hoping for. Maybe I'm just not big into dipping a chinese donut into soy milk. It tasted bland to me.

1trVTQT8vOEsssqyecvMMg.text: We went to this restaurant for the soup dumplings on Sunday morning at around 10, and they said they would not make them. Next morning we returned very early at 7:30 in hopes they would make them and they refused yet again. If the soup dumplings are on your menu, they should actually be available. Very irritated.

XFRIc9Vr8juRzVPg3cP9SA.text: Sweet potato cake is so good!! Egg pancake is good too!! Most of the stuff is great here!!

HecnwWFbZvzDvjwH9nHi6Q.text: I might come back if i ever feel like eating my favorite again.    The owner of this restaurant is the same one from Champion on Spring Mountain Rd.  It's in the same mall of the old SF supermarket.    Please don't let the their service discourage you from visiting this place again.  This is how their service works.  When you get there, they don't really seat you, you just find a spot to sit, get your own water from the dispenser and grab your own utensils for food.  You can either go up to the counter to get their menu or you can wait for them.  Either way.  Their service isn't the best but that's how they roll.  I'm only giving this place 2 stars because I've read the review from someone else about this place and he said that they didn't have some of the items on the menu.  So I decided to wait a few days afterwards to go.  But, the items that were unavailable from the previous review, was still UNAVAILABLE.  This makes me wonder, if they even have the man power to run a business like this.  Why did they advertise Taiwanses deli when they don't have soy drinks? Why they don't have shao lung bao? Waitress said to me that since they are so busy, the chef is unable to make the shao lung bao.  (Oh really?  Do you want the business from me? Seriuosly?  No? I guess not!)    It just doesn't make sense to me why they don't hire more people to help outside and inside of the kitchen?  Why don't they better prepare themselves? They've been in business for a while week already and not to mention, they only moved over from their previous business, so they have experience already.    I then suddenly remember how the sluggish atmosphere is like from the old champion restaurant.  It's the exact same thing.  They probably want to improve business but don't really know how to handle a busy business within their management.    I want to review on their dam dam mein.  It used to taste really good at the old location, and i expected it to be the same. But it didnt' taste the same.  Not only did they not have the appropriate  that they were supposed to serve , the peanut sauce was really bland.    They didn't have soy that i wanted to drink, they didn't have the siu lung bao, that i wanted.  I ordered my normal favorite and it turned out horrible.  I also ordered the Beef noodle which didn't taste great either.    Over all, i was really disappointed in their management.  I hope their services will improve in the future.  I will not be back there for a while.

1SNBRKUh-dZCZstZ499X4A.text: They barely recognized we were there.  If my mother in law was there it may of been of been easier. Lol.  It's traditional type of Taiwanese food joint so you have to know what you are ordering. My fiance had noodles and he said his mom's was a lot better.  I had stinky tofu, but they only had the deep fried one.  That seems to be the favorite dish.  I wanted to try the other style but they ran out.  I'll give it a shot next time, we will have to catch them in the morning versus the evening.

FMHaAwCWbYrXQVadhb83Bg.text: The owner is nice, if you get alot of little things like the dim sum items it can get expensive pretty quick, I like the shaved ice here, for the hot summer vegas days. I haven't tried the main dishes. But I am sure they are good, everything I have tried so far was good. Shaved ice is my fav so far tho. Vegas is to hot to eat soup or hot dishes usually. Except in winter.

bRRJTACiVYFeg_5EdPIT_Q.text: We went to have Taiwanese breakfast on Sunday morning. We got there just before 11:30am and they served breakfast only until 11:30am. It was after 11:30am by the time we got a table (it was packed in there), but luckily they still took our order for the breakfast special. It consisted of hot soya bean milk, Chinese donut, and a pastry bun. This typical Taiwanese breakfast combo was not bad for $3.99. The soya bean was very strong flavor and made fresh at the restaurant. The Chinese deep fried donut was not quite up to par, not chewy and holey enough, but okay. The pastry bun was flaky, although for my taste buds, I would prefer it to be filled with some sort of meat. We also ordered xiu long bao, salty rice roll and a beef sandwich. The xiu long bao was quite tasty, but a little on the small size. The salty rice roll which consists of glutinous rice wrapped around a Chinese donut with dried pork jerky was not bad. It tastes quite good, but the Chinese donut inside was overcooked and a little too hard for my liking. Lastly, the beef sandwich had slices of marinated beef in the pastry bun. It didn't come with any sauce, so to me the sandwich was on the dry side. The flavor of the beef could also be improved. So overall, I think this place is only deserving of 2.5 stars. Oh, one last note, although they have waitress to serve you, they also have a table at the side, where you can pick up your own plastic utensils, napkins and get your own water to drink. Pretty weird huh?

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Xio Long Bao
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef sandwich
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Special breakfast combo $3.99 (7:00am to 11:30am only)

jPpkRfpGylJFwup-blzz4g.text: Don't mind the 3 star rating. This place is de-ricious.  What's up with everyone giving this place 2-3 stars because the "service was terrible". My family and I went here twice in one day and did not experience anything remotely close to bad service, despite every table being taken. In fact, the owner of the place actually came over and had a 15 minute conversation about how the place got start, what types of dishes we should try and what other places we should check out in the area.   I took my parents to Vegas for the first time. The only request that they had was to check out Chinatown (yes, my parents are lame). I looked up a breakfast place to eat and found Yi Mei. I was a fan of the other locations in Southern California, so I decided to take them there. We were greeted right away and wait about 2-3 minutes for them to clear off a table. Unlike the other locations that I've been to, they had a huge menu included lunch & dinner items. I want apologize in advance, since I have to translate the dishes from Chinese to English and completely making the food sound unappetizing. We ordered a variety of things...soy milk (sweet and salty), Taiwanese style donut, scallion pancake, beef sandwich, "meat round" (Taiwanese dish with meat filling wrapped by a translucent rice cake). I have to say, growing up with Taiwanese food and living in Taiwan for a year, this place is as authentic as it gets. The food is made fresh to order and they do it very well. With all the food we ordered, the total was still less than 30 dollars.   If you want a nice break from the expensive casino food, this place is a great option.   A little about my credentials:  I first got into cooking & food when I was in college. After being rejected by numerous girls and getting zero action, I decided it was time for a change. I needed a new makeover to boost my geeky, engineering image. I applied for a cooking position at a Mediterranean-Italian  Restaurant near my home and learned to cook all sorts of pastas and dishes. I never became a professional chef, but I continue to enjoy & love food. 8 years later and 55 lbs heavier, I am now an engineer that travels all over the world trying new foods and learning about different cultures.

eZqewpFJp59k1iCKxKoK2A.text: Really cute and quaint deli! Beautiful service! Beef wraps delicious!

4_OOGrlwrhEnWsnFYO8LbQ.text: Sadness can only be cured with fried Chinese Doughnuts and Hot Soy Milk. An early trip to drop off my sister to the airport alloted me an hour before I had to get to work. An hour is a strange amount of time. Not enough to devout too much time to any activity, but long enough to make it difficult to fill.   My job is close to Chinatown and I have wanted to try Taiwanese breakfast. I love my hot soy milk ($1.75) and youtiao ($1.75). Other than that, I am not familiar with this style of dining. The soy milk is thin and comes plain. The waitress told me that I would need to add sugar to sweeten it. Maybe after some of the reviews saying it was too sweet got them to just serve it this way. I am a fan of self service and added just a little to lightly adjust the flavor. Unsure about the sizes of the dishes here, I decided to order one at a time. Lucky, for me, because the Egg Cake and Chinese Doughnuts ($4.75) is a bountiful feast. One stick of two doughnuts are wrapped in a large egg pancake. When the waitress came around, she had many little plates on a tray and dealt them out to multiple tables. I eyed the largest plate and wondered what it was. Wonder no more, because it was mine. I debated on whether or not to finish my meal, but the perfectly brown dough begged not to be wasted. The savory and soft egg gave amazing textural contrast to the deep fried bread. They fry them up to order, because on the bottom of my plate, there was a little puddle of oil. Usually this is a turn off, but the taste makes it easy to overlook a normal infraction.  At $7.03, I ended up with a delicious meal at fast food prices. I would like to come back and try some of the pickled mustard green or vegetable buns.   For a large restaurant, there is only one waitress attending to guest and cashiering. She apologized a few times for the wait time, but it was nothing to get hung up over.

V_g9dyEpTzB8BjUjT28IqA.text: The next time (and every time) I'm in Vegas, I will be back here for the steamed vegetable buns. Amazingly good!

LuNoUioTinhyKTtVJ5ZxkA.text: Its hard to find authentic Taiwanese food back in Hawaii where I'm from, so I was excited to give this place a shot.  There are some other good places nearby, so if I ran into something repulsive, it would be ready to rebound.  I tried the spicy tendon and beef noodle soup since I long craved fort mama's homemade version.  Not quite as good as mom's, but it never is, an I right? All in all, not bad, in fact, above average.  Service is like most mom and pop joints, you enter to find a person you thought is a customer eating their food stand up and take our order.  This bothers people that aren't use to this.  I am a consumer that appreciate good food and not so much the service, especially if you understand cultural differences.  After all, I came to eat, not to make a new buddy.  I guess it comes with the territory since I seen it all, almost.

7ObLXRJUabjZtQNdv_3l_A.text: Not bad for a "Taiwan Deli" in Las Vegas...being from Southern California it's harder to compare these restaurants in Vegas to the quality of the ones in LA.  The Green Onion Pancake had no flavor because they didn't put much salt in it but it was also not as greasy as most places which was kinda good.  Plenty of dishes to choose from I got my standard chicken and rice...but it just wasn't the same as other restaurants.

U9aazZoxiji07BhKlpwTEQ.text: I wanted some hot soybean milk and Chinese donut (oil stick) for a while so finally, this morning I had some. We arrived at Taiwan deli at 10:45 and luckily no wait. There was one table open so we sat down quickly. Here are the things we ordered: Chinese donut (oil stick): 1.65-4* Sweet soy bean milk: 1.60-4* Baked sandwich: 1.65-very plain. Don't order it by itself Baked beef sandwich with mustard green: 3.5-4*very beefy and flavorful after adding soy sauce. Yum Radish pancake: 2.99-2*Because I had better Steamed dumplings w/pork and leeks(little dragon buns): 4.99-2*very dry! No no no!  Yeah, it's pretty hard to screw up the soybean milk and oil sticks, but it's pretty hard to find that combination here in Vegas so I am giving them 4* on that. Those prices that I have next to the items are a la carte prices. Right now, they do have a breakfast special, which is the soybean milk, Chinese donuts, and baked sandwich fir $3.99, which saves almost a dollar. All in all, I do like to have a traditional breakfast of soybean milk and oil sticks once in a while and this will be my go to place.

ahhq70T0SqKDcG0bTUo3xA.text: I was fortunate to be introduced to this place by a friend (who actually was visting Las Vegas). Definitely a place that I know frequent when I am craving True Taiwanese breakfast food or spicy beef noodle soup. And every time I do check in here, my friend from LA is jealous!  I havent had that many things on the menu here, but thats only because I tend to order the same thing! For $2.25 you can get the salty rice rolls (with preserved pork inside). These things are so good and they are made fresh to order! The other thing I always get is the spicy beef noodle soup with tendon. This rivals many of the places I go to in LA and the portion is actually bigger here. Definitely some comfort food, especially after a long night of drinking.  If you are craving some authentic Taiwanese food, this is the place to be!

N4js2uJBk26WY350zUfrTg.text: I was so excited to spot this place on my trip in Vegas and entered hoping for some authentic Taiwanese breakfast. The food was cheap and the servers very polite. I had a fantuan with a bowl of rice drink (mijian). The portions were rather small and the taste underwhelming.

-7AZss2Qg86VWoNflqff_w.text: I'm a cooking instructor in China and my parents are from Taiwan and we love this place.  I usually don't look forward to eating Chinese food when I visit from China (too much there), but this is one of the only places I'll go because it reminds me of Taiwan.  The owner's daughter makes a lot of the food that they serve and she is very passionate about food.  I kept asking her questions on how to make a lot of the food and she enthusiastically walked me through her processes.  She even brought out the dough for some of the Youtiao (chinese donutto show me how to do it, and explained the length of time it takes her to do it.  They also get up early to make their own soy milk.  The spicy beef and tendon noodle soup is delicious.  My mother also tends to get the stinky tofu there, which I very much enjoy too.  They also sell frozen products like Zongzi (Chinese stuffed banana leaf filled with rice and other goods).  They stand by all of the products they make and are very authentic.  The wontons in spicy oil are also very good here.  The service is just laid back and relaxed.  Expect to get your own water from the dispenser and help yourself to the sodas in the fridge.  Also very affordable.

wSo-uk1uOKQx1tNBXYGIPA.text: I love this place.  I went there 2 times in 2 days because I loved it to much.  Their soy milk is awesome.... I would recommend getting one sweet and one non sweet and mixing them (I like a little sugar...but not a lot).  Their "rice balls" or more like "rice burritos" is amazing... get the salted one.  It has a chinese donut and pork sung (dried pork) inside.  Other things I would recommend is the vegetable and pork buns, their beef wraps and also their egg pancake for breakfast.

Of1gH7MeBqYAQbLjDWT3ig.text: This is Taiwanese breakfast place and it is great for the price and value. My kids love their Chinese steamed mini pork bun Chinese called !If you are passing by Las Vegas and looking for Chinese breakfast place this is the place to go! They also sell other Chinese goodies like duck tongs and wings! Yum yum! Everything is home made!!!

yEvoRKVA2jwLgYuVg492KQ.text: We went there on a Wednesday morning in a hurry. There was a lot of people in the restaurant. I think they were from a vacation tour. I was not very happy to see that they cater to large groups like that, because the limited time we have.   It took awhile before we ordered, but the food came out quick. All the items we ordered were pre-made anyway. We ordered 2 hot soy milk, 2 youtiao(fried dough), 1 shaobing( baked sesame cake). The food was pretty good. I was disappointed that they don't offer the special anymore though.

SCum9ab1U84AI-kc__eA6w.text: Great and very authentic Taiwanese food. It's like stepping into a Taiwanese restaurant. Service is more 2-3 stars, but authenticity and good food takes it to 5 stars for me! We go here so much they know us and my daughter who can order her own food! In Mandarin!  Service is a mix between wait service and "help yourself". For water and tea, you usually have to get it yourself. They'll take your order and bring food and other things you need (when you ask), but then you pay at the register.

A9LoGV6yGWp_u0-vj8JSMg.text: Hands down the best Taiwanese deep fried pork chop I've ever had. The pork chop was huge, tender, not greasy or overly breaded. I finished the entire plate, was stuffed and was still gnawing on the bone like a caveman afterwards. The minced pork and egg over the rice was fantastic. One thing that was lacking entirely however  is the pickled veggies. My wife ordered the spicy beef noodle soup. Also tasty and tender. Her only complaint was that they cut all the noodles so they're pretty short. The steamed dumplings were good however I wished there was more hot broth inside of it. Overall we were very impressed. This will be our go to lunch spot on all our Vegas trips from now on.

BRj-1w8wMeG_EjPX1whLqA.text: I woke up this Sunday morning with a craving for fried donut and wonton soup.  My mom and I went to Wendy's noodle cafe and realized they only open for lunch.  So we decided to try this place since I've read some reviews and heard about this place from a few friends.    I cannot understand how people are giving this place 4 or 5 stars.   Where do I begin...first the service was horrible.  Right after we came in I realized this is one of those places where you seat yourself.  I don't have a problem with that so we picked a table.   After 10 minutes wait we still hadn't seen any service in the entire dining area so I went to the counter while thinking maybe this is a place where you order at the counter and serve yourself.  The lady at the counter told me she'll come right out to take our order.  Another 5 minutes later a different waitress came out and started taking order from a group of people who came in after us.  So I had to go to the counter again and the waitress who told me she'd be right out was just hanging there doing nothing.    Very much like the service the food was also a disappointment.  I wanted something soupy but they didn't have any soup (including the beef noodle soup) available for breakfast.  So I ordered fried donut, beef pancake and soy milk.  The fried dough (or donut) was probably the worst I've had.  Part of it was overly crunchy and the rest was like chewing on paper.    The beef pancake came out in saran wrap which made it look not freshly made.  It's not horrible but I've definitely had better ones (like the one in China Ma Ma).  The taste was bland and I had to use a lot of hot sauce.  The flaky outside was so crispy that it just fell all over on the table when I tried to unwrap it.  What a mess.    I expected soy milk but I think she brought me the soy tofu thing.  Anyway the dish already had fried donuts in there.  Any decent waitress would warn the customers that they may not need the additional order of fried donut but apparently not here.  The dish was below average from presentation to taste.    Overall I don't think there's anything about this place that will make me go back.  They may have better things for lunch or dinner but I don't really care about finding that out.

vFQQIbA1LhyThJ0BJvXyxQ.text: I gotta bump up the rating to one more star for an improvement in the juicy dumplings (xiao long bao) and potstickers (guo tie).  We went for a lazy Sunday morning breakfast at Yi Mei.  We mainly went for noodles, but we didn't know that noodle dishes are not available until lunch time.  It definitely worked out because the server recommended the pot stickers.  1.  Pot Stickers - Juicy lil' baby morsels of meat and add in the crispy fried skin 2.  Juicy Pork Dumplings - improvement!  the meat wasn't as salty.  the skin was thinner, which is better in my mind.  juicier but still not as juicy as din tai fung caliber  Conclusion:  up 1 star for improvement and juicy and flavor factors!

XV_wyVNvboUchgSYUGHeaQ.text: Maybe it's Las Vegas and no expectation should be given to the Chinese food, but this place is really nothing more than normal as to the food quality. The only benefit you may get is the opportunity to have some traditional Chinese breakfast. They have a lot of choices, mainly from Taiwan and Tianjin. The staff were extremely inefficient and inattentive. We complained a few times about the speed of getting our food, but nobody cared and a boy waiter even coldly said "talk to whoever took your order" (although he clearly knew who took our order, he even did not tell that waitress who kept staying behind the counter when walked by). One star given to the choice of food, but would strongly advise this restaurant to get improved.

iRwg-GTwAlvcq1qvRGs3Dg.text: They overcharge big time for the oyster omelette and skimped on the ingredient. I counted two partial slivers of very stale oysters, which left a really bad taste at $8-9 a dish. I also ordered a fried chicken rice plate, which was probably the most dry, flavorless fried chicken steak I've ever had.

-5s47JcVw1pbsr9Sku4KoA.text: The food was great. Reasonable prices. However, service was not good at all. Waitress fight with the customers next to us. Because, the potstickers they ordered which took so long, and they did not want it. The waitresses insisted they have to pay for it and take it as to go. The service we experienced was not as bad as they did. But not good as well. Our waitress showed no patience and no smile while we ordered.

IB23ad-J0D8MqA1eOZRhoA.text: I give it 5 stars because you get a lot of handmade quality for what you spend.  This place offers some of the best value for a quick eat.

FV8Nzd4-gPSd3ETeQdtzqA.text: Very good food and owner is very friendly. She came talked to us like she knew us for long times.  Too bad we are only here for vacation, otherwise I would be their loyal costumer.

IiNGk8aTLAi4Xp66Fg-22w.text: Came here when a Taiwanese friend was in town, because of course I need help ordering. Overall, the food was amazing! But this place is a small, family owned place, that only makes up for the shabby appearance by the quality food. I will say that it gave it an authentic feel - grandpa was sitting at the table next to us packaging freshly roasted peanuts and I'm pretty sure I saw grandma back in the kitchen. Definitely coming back here, I only hope I can replicate the amazing meal I had here without help ordering. But then again, even  the dishes that I'd normally avoid (because I don't know much about authentic Taiwanese cuisine) like the oyster pancake/omelette, were so surprisingly good! My friend lives in DC and kept saying she couldn't believe the authentic dishes they served because she had otherwise only had them when she was actually in Taiwan.

iOWKceHmKmpW7h-yRkM8ZQ.text: I love all Taiwanese food, but especially taiwanese breakfast, so I was super psyched to find this place.  Here's what we ordered:  oyster pancake - bleh bleh bleh.  the sauce was was REALLY cinnamon-y, and not thick enough.  It really didn't taste like oh ah jian (forgive me, I don't know ping ying) at all.  Plus, it was 7 whopping bucks.  dan bing (egg pancake) - really eggy, but the bing wasn't crispy enough.  it's hard to mess up dan bing though.  salty soy milk (shian do jiang) - VERY tasty.  It's a small-ish bowl, but for 3 bucks, it's not bad.  Lots of vinegar and pork sung.  Would definitely order again.  pork chop rice - The pork chop was okay (but I'm not a huge fan of pork chop), but the seasoned pork and vegetable on the side (the zho zhau) was REALLY good.   stewed pig ear and bean curd - this tasted pretty much like you would expect.  Decent flavor, though the bean curd was a bit on the salty side.  They have tons of other breakfast items that we didn't get a chance to try, but will update once we come back.  I would have given this place 4 stars if not for that horrid oyster pancake.  Plus, any place that serves decent taiwanese food in the middle of the desert is alright in my book! :)

DVqVUWPVFz8QE3KmC3Ml4w.text: Worst place ever, we been here for 20minutes for our food, the owner said that this is not fastfood place, everyone else came after us already got there food, the servers didn't even tell us that we needed to wait for a bowl of noodle.  It a dry place too.

iPPdD6k4zyMXoZYgfdGIqA.text: Nice authentic food with fast service. We had rice milk, soy milk, rice roll, fish ball soup and wrapped rice dumpling. They all tasted good and had great portion. But this place is a little crowed and busy, maybe due to holiday season. As a previous reviewer mentioned they do seem to add 15% tip by default no matter dine in or take out, which is uncommon for small groups below 6 people. I feel bad and sad about this "clever" trick, so minus one star.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States

mukvs1hfNNlj6QY7EsRCxQ.text: Came here for Taiwanese breakfast, and for the most part, it was what I expected. I've seen some people review that the service isn't great or that the owner is snappy, but for us she was very accommodating with us (with that somewhat curt attitude lol). So at least to me, if you look past that, service is great.   Food is pretty good, not too salty. Only the quantity is somewhat smaller than I hoped. The radish pancake only came with two pieces, and the beef roll was only three pieces, although it came with pickled cucumber and cabbage.   I'll keep this place in mind, I'd come back to check out the lunch menu.   One thing that I did appreciate about this place is the reason it has it's hours so short. Sure, it's short and only in the morning (they close at 3PM). The reason is because the owner can then go home and spend time with her dad and cook for him too. She does accommodate people who may want to come in later. She had a party call in maybe a couple days before saying they wanted to bring people there but it would be after closing time, maybe around 4PM. With that heads up, she was willing to open up for them. Quite nice!

_MzflZ3G5RD9u4-13MDJ7A.text: I've been looking for a Chinese breakfast place out here that is up to par with what I could get in California, and this place is the best I've tried in Las Vegas...and I've been out here for over 10 years. Service leaves a little to be desired, but that's typical for these places. Food is super authentic and exactly what I was looking for!

JYYY09zO95o6fnuhruW1Jg.text: Disappointed.. it seems like soybean milk is diluted by a lot of water as it taste super plain.  Salty rice roll is just average...maybe I should try another flavor. Beef roll is the only one I'm satisfied with for this meal. Beef is tender and soaked up tasty flavor. It may taste better if the roll can be a little bit more crispy (not fully crispy)

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States

O1IY1ezUZo5u-ttew8ssuA.text: The waiter was very nice to us. The food was average. I didn't like the rice balls at all.

CPhSUrtINY7DxoJHfQjDCQ.text: Oyster pancake is closest to Taiwan I've had. Xlb was juicy but temperature was a bit off.no sticky tofu as vendor was closed per hostess. Yeah service sucks, but that's the norm at lower grade Chinese joints. For the deli grade, it's the perfect. If you want 1st rate service you got to go to hotel or more costly joints

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oyster pancake... very close to Taiwan.  Real oysters!

rJywGLm8_ITusUiGECefIw.text: The place is Chinese style breakfast traditional. Most likely is Chinese people will go for breakfast. It is not the best one but it is fine. Specially, it is Las Vegas.

edsAGA4ZTjfgIbJIcE0HGg.text: I might up my rating after I come back and try more of their dishes, but for today, 3 stars. I'm excited that I will soon be able to get this kind of food when I move to Vegas though; it's already a huge step up from what's available in Richmond, VA.  The inside is very simple and casual and has several tables. Service is mediocre, and I didn't expect much, but usually Taiwanese people are more friendly (granted, some of the waitresses were mainland Chinese).   The menu is extensive and prices are very reasonable, so that's a plus. I ordered the salty rice ball, salty soymilk, and pickled cucumber appetizer (please see my photo captions for the exact dish names as they are listed in the menu). The fried dough stick () inside the salty rice ball was not crispy at all, which was a bit disappointing. Salty soymilk was decent, but I've had much better (and there was no white vinegar on the table or served with it if you wanted to add some). The pickled cucumbers were great though!  Overall, portions are generous for the price (i.e. good value) and the food is not bad, but I guess I just had higher expectations. I will still be back to try more off the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salted rice roll (鹹飯糰), salted soybean milk (鹹豆漿), and pickled cucumber (涼拌黃瓜).
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Exterior.

gfvwKiOUw1PhFNWZyxG1Cw.text: We tried the green onion pancake w egg, sweet tofu dessert with peanuts and rice burrito. The only thing that was good was the rice burrito. The green onion pancake barely had any greens and it was very doughy. The sweet tofu said it was to come with peanuts but it didn't. It should have came with a brown sugar ginger syrup but instead white sugar was already incorporated without any ginger.   I'll probably come back but only for the rice burrito since this is the only place in town that serves it.

E3RmkT19lOR2Y04bcsXaSw.text: No service, came for breakfast on the good reviews from fellow Yelpers.  She sat us inside this other section as we were just 2.  Waited 10 mins then left.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States

V_WTel1y8WszubVSdgL-GQ.text: New location on Spring Mountain and Arville (across the street from Sushi Kaya).  It may be a bit difficult to come here if you are not familiar with Taiwanese cuisine, as the menu is non-descriptive and there is a bit of a language barrier. I get by using Yelp photos to determine what I will be eating and blindly choosing an item. Yi Mei Champion seems popular for a typical Taiwanese breakfast. I've noticed that this is usually composed of their salted soy milk or salted bean curd, which is are light soy-saucey broths with tofu and some pork floss for saltiness. I add chili oil and it's nice, warm, and homey tasting. Order some extra oily Chinese fried donuts to dip into it! May not be super healthy, but it's super comforting.  Other things my boyfriend and I have tried: -Noodle dishes have been good.. can't give much advice on how to order these as we randomly chose them. -Radish w/ eggs. More like a soft dough fried in eggs. I enjoy this.  -Chili oil bean curd- very salty, buttery tofu with a hint of spice. Good to eat with rice or spread on something bland. -Beef roll - pass. dry and pre-made. Nothing special.  I saw a lady near the front making large crepe-looking dishes with a gooey looking dough. Didn't get a chance to ask about it.. but I would totally appreciate if anyone knows and would like to enlighten me about it!  Don't expect amazing service. Do expect quick and homey food that is cheap.

Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Radish w/ egg. Like fried dough covered in egg
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chili oil bean curd. Salty and good with rice

9lprF1lYd61hNT6odBveug.text: Worst breakfast experience ever. Would never come back again, the server is very impolite. The food is alright, but nothing special. Was asking them do not add green onion when we were ordering, they directly say that is impou, asked why, the answer was "Don't know, we just can not do that, you can just eat what they ordered."

heTPJuLq4R1sgKiAirUGWw.text: Beef soup noodle is a must. The price is cheap and the food is very good. Definitely will come back next time

5pOMO6KvCKUbIMwdUMWXrA.text: So we were in Vegas on vacation with the family and we decided to try some Taiwanese food. I looked on Yelp to see what options we had it we didn't want to stray too far. So we decided to come here and try some dishes. We ordered Oyster omelet and rice cake bowl with a few other dishes.  The rice cake bowl was probably the worse I've ever had and everything else was just ok at best.  Maybe we didn't try the best they had to offer but these are the staples of Taiwanese food.  Prices were high too.  Will try a different place next time we're in Vegas.

0ZD_0KED-p9NmgWe8VMtbA.text: We had breakfast here while vacationing in Las Vegas. This restaurant is located in a Asian/Chinatown district of Las Vegas off of Spring Mountain Rd in a little mall next to a tire shop. The service was good and the food was very good. My Taiwanese spouse loved the food especially the oyster dish and found the food very authentic Taiwanese. I had the spicy beef noodle soup which comes in a large bowl. It was a bit spicy but delicious. We ordered quite a bit of food and the cost was very good for the amount of food we had. I would recommend.

O4Jx8LCOL4TFF7AO-e1SWQ.text: Authentic Taiwanese restaurant, great food and reasonable prices. A must on my itinerary evey time in Vegas!!

ZVHGlEUbPwSvagt6o_Vrhw.text: The food was really good! The pig ears were super delicious, the soy milk was amazing and the you tiao was very good. The lady who served us was kind and attentive, which is always a plus. However, I deducted one star because the dumplings I ordered were just kind of subpar. But if you're looking for a solid Taiwanese breakfast, this shop does it better than most! If I'm ever in the area, I'll definitely visit again!

wZMPbP-EwcMTYqo1QqSTTw.text: So... since my last review I believe they moved to a bigger location. It was nearly empty when I came back this month. The food seemed to be ok, and not as good as I remembered. The kicker is when I found a strand of hair in my xiao long bao. I was completely turned off after that. I didn't tell my waiter because he seemed like a nice guy, but it's unappetizing to find things like that especially for breakfast when you're barely awake. Not sure if I will return.

YOvl-JEfXHN58G96XmSiOw.text: Not the place to go if you are looking for great dinning experience, but if you want delicious food for cheap, this is the place! All their tables are large fitted for family so no worries if you have a big group.   Our orders were taken quickly, water was brought out as soon as we asked for it, and food came out within minutes! Their minced pork over rice was so good! Great flavors and great portion, came out super quick...can be a little greasy but that is what makes it so good!  The pork chop rice was HUGE! Came with minced pork also, veggies and was big enough for two to share. The beef roll was also good, came with pickled cucumbers and fermented cabbage that was similar to kim-chi.   I didn't really care for the oyster omelet with the sauce on top, their soup dumpling was decent, juicy but the lacked in flavor a little.   Overall i will definitely come back for the rice and I really want to try their breakfast items. We used to always go to this other place for Taiwanese style breakfast, although that place was good they get really busy and food takes awhile. Looking forward to trying the breakfast menu here.

2843EANzSRLPmc_60R4c_A.text: These place has become a regular spot ever since my early pregnancy at their last location.  The owner is always there and so friendly.    My go to Favorite is Salty Tofu Bowl, sticky rice roll and Chinese donut wrapped in an egg pancake.  It is a savory breakfast that fills me up.  It is just delicious.  I am happy now that my daughter is eating big people food we can introduce her to new flavors to open her taste buds.  I come her at least once a month and will continue to do so.

y36glq-Nu1x0VurM97eJNw.text: Perhaps one of the best experience I've had ever in a environment of just total friendly people and excellent service period with the most delectable and unusual breakfast items I've ever had I enjoyed every single thing that I was provided and would recommend this to anybody to try

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Me and the owner Ms. Yu!

DncjhhBkk7lriV9coaXidA.text: Omg!  This place is amazing,  not fancy typical  mom and pops placel but the food was incredible!  This is real Tiwanese style street food. I had the spicy TENDON and Beef soup and it was so amazing. The portion was extremely generous.  What a hidden gem, I will definitely come back and try everything on the menu . Highly recommended.  Ps I believed that I was the only non chinese person here so you know it has to be pretty darn authentic

XQnwcRc9-bim3sZm-FK9Vg.text: I went here with my friend for lunch. We had both just went to Taiwan and were very excited to remember the great food we experienced there. Although we did eat and leave full, we felt that the food wasn't the same. Some of the ingredients did not seem high quality. The sauces weren't as flavorful, either. Is there any good, flavorful, authentic Taiwanese food in Vegas?

V2GWdUW8Wv56Fk-zmEasVg.text: Ask a Chinese person to take you here...your experience depends on it. No one speaks English...and no one will try to understand you if you don't speak Chinese.  My first experience here was great, I came with a fellow yelper, Mike C. and had him order everything. My order came out and everything fine.  My second visit was a desperate one. I originally stopped by Asian BBQ and noodles but they're closed on Fridays :( So...I decided to drive across the street.   I ordered the beef noodle soup and asked if they could add wontons in it...weird I know but I was craving both. First they brought out a bowl of wontons in beef broth which is understandable and forgivable because of the language barrier. They took it back...added the beef and the noodles...everything looked great until I started eating. The wontons were falling apart as soon as I tried picking them up with my chopsticks. I was starving so I ignored this and continued eating until I bit into one of the wontons and realized that it was still pink...undercooked. Gross...-_-  The service here is non existent... They have a water cooler and Styrofoam cups if you need water... Feel free to walk up and get it yourself. Same goes for napkins.   This experience was probably an extreme of how bad a meal could go wrong here...but I will not be back. This decision was made after considering that the first visit was decent. There are just too many better options in the area.

GAI2Q_PKFdarfDVfKTzMFw.text: I cannot stop thinking about their mushroom and pork buns!  They're filled with stuffing and the bun is a soft pillowy exterior.  They have traditional Chinese breakfast and the prices are pretty cheap.  Come here for those buns if for nothing else.

Jop_yUucWEXNHbCNtWijxA.text: Super delicious find in Vegas! I love a good Taiwanese breakfast + this was perfectly satisfying. The staff is super nice + helpful. Now the food: - soybean milk: perfect, hit the spot! - Chinese donut: fresh, but really oily, though I ate most of it so I guess it wasn't that bad :) I would order it again. - Beef roll: the most disappointing thing we ordered. Not like the beef rolls I've had before. It looks really tasty but it didn't taste like anything. I would not get this again. I'd try the beef pocket instead. I saw other people eating that + it looked delicious. - salted rice roll: my favorite thing + I don't know why it's not more common, like onigiri...anyways perfect rice to meat floss to Chinese donuts proportions.  I could eat this every day. - Shanghai dumplings: really tasty but the skins were all broken so there was no soup, but still really tasty.

E5uSXWfAj_0Og_GNdS8OnQ.text: Came here for one thing only: STINKY TOFU  Decent. Fairly stinky. Flavor is just ok. I do like the kim chi that came with it.   Had the green onion pancake... tasted like prepackaged store-bought. SKIP unless you're really craving it!!!

1suaYbuhaBRJdJHMGo22TA.text: Great place for lunch. Yet to try breakfast. Lovely owners, didn't charge extra for a new melon tea when I split it open all over the table.

Ow_1938VOX5xNARMZ8VmKA.text: Authentic Taiwanese breakfast that can't be found even in NYC. Perfect ending for our trip. Be aware that they open till only 3PM on Sunday. I was there 6PM.... But anyway, went back next morning and got so far the most authentic rice ball and Chinese cruller I ever had in US. Too bad I had to leave at noon. Otherwise I'll have another meal there for their famous beef noodle.

aSrIVCRi9zORxi1kq48KCQ.text: Authentic Taiwanese food. Every bite feels like it was made by mom (hopefully your mom was a great cook). My friend's mom, who is Taiwanese, buys in bulk here and takes it back to her state!  Location: Chinatown, plenty of parking in the plaza  Ambiance: Mom and Pop. Friendly owner and chef! Good for groups/family.   Food:  1. Spicy beef noodle soup -- 5 stars  They make their own noodles and the consistency is chewy and soft. These noodles soak up the soup without losing their texture.  2. Scallion pancake -- 5 stars Not doughy at all! Crispy! 3. Tea eggs -- 4 stars Take it to go and eat it the next day for breakfast! 4. Soup dumplings -- 4 stars The wrapper is a bit thick. The pork and veggie filling is tasty!  Price: For all this food, we had plenty of left overs for 2. About $13/person.   I don't think they have an alcohol license, but if you ask them politely they are open to BYOB.

DFgmLLPW-aGmRFRCs-wGOQ.text: Just arrived in Las Vegas and the first thing to do is to..... eat Taiwanese food!   Anyways, this is a small hole in the wall restaurant in Vegas' Chinatown. Not too clean. Service is ok. Looks like they have a steady stream of customers.   We wanted the minced pork with noodles and was told there were no more noodles for that dish left. I guess they sell out by the afternoon? The thing is that they can buy it at the 99 Ranch Market almost right next door. We settled for the minced pork with rice.   We also ordered two different types of noodle bowls- the noodles with the dumplings and thin noodles.  The food overall was not too bad.   The portions were huge; we couldn't finish everything. The prices were cheap compared to Southern California.

-xsvFs0mquHJgakmWjD3zw.text: New location is over on Spring Mt and Arville. It sits right behind the AM/PM. Straight to the point kind of food. Good price and good portions. A must is: Spicy Beef Noodles (and tendon optional, but recommended), Crispy roll w/pork and also the mushroom and pork bun. These are my top 3 recommendation for first timers. Service speed depends on how packed the place is. I'm usually in and out in about 15 minutes or less. It's a great hidden gem, that us locals go to. And the noodles are as homemade as you can get.

eFm-SZAFzUM6Bea9RZ0M6A.text: I've been on the hunt for a good Taiwanese restaurant and decided to try out this place based on their reviews. I have to say that my experience was mediocre.   From the reviews that I read, the service sounded like it was terrible and even worse for people who can't speak Taiwanese. That wasn't the case for me because as I came in with my husband and 2 kids we seated ourselves and within a few minutes we had someone come to take our order. I don't speak Taiwanese so I ordered everything in English and the girl who took my order understood everything. Maybe I got lucky that day!   Within 5-10 minutes our food started coming out and everything was out within 10 minutes. I was pretty happy about that! We ordered a variety of things because I wanted to try out my favorite dishes: green onion pancake, oyster omelette, juicy pork dumplings, and beef noodle soup. I also ordered the hot soybean milk... Which was so fresh and delicious! Made me feel like a kid again!   Here's a breakdown of the food: 1) green onion pancake- too thick for my liking. I like the thinner and crispier ones. The flavor was good but it was a little too doughy for me. 2) oyster omelette- the omelet itself was great! But the sauce they put on top was too sweet. 3) juicy pork dumplings- amazing. Perfect. The ginger soy dipping sauce complemented the dumplings perfectly. I will come back for more! 4) spicy beef noodle soup- it was good and not too spicy. I wish they gave me more of the pickled mustard greens though.   So was this one of the best Taiwanese restaurants I've been to? No... But the prices are good and the food, well, you just have to try it to see if you like it more than not.

LDDZkBMQnJ7G6z6TB504Vg.text: It's average taiwanese food, but for Vegas standards, it really pretty good.  I had the stinky tofu (not stinky at all), beef stew noodle soup, and oyster egg pancake.  The stinky tofu tastied just like regular fried tofu.  The beef stew noodle soup was delicious, probably the best seller in the store, the oyster egg pancake smelled fishy, not recommended.    But they also serve soy milk, with pastry, so if you're craving that it's probably a dependable place to go to.

9kY1dEgWygVo4JeukwP4tw.text: I always have a soft spot for Taiwanese breakfast. Some soybean milk and fan tuan are the best way to start a day. It is rather hard for me to not enjoy them unless they are really badly prepared. (something I have yet to experience)  Yi Mei is one of the few off the strip places that open super early. There were no wait when I arrived before 9 but the restaurant was quickly filled to capacity an hour later.  I think 3.5 stars is a fairly accurate rating for Yi Mei. It is much better than 3 but not quite 4 stars yet. Soybean milk and fan tuan (rice roll) were nicely done. The leek filling pancake was a bit too hard and too oily. Steamed Pork and Vegetable Bun was generous in portion and quite tasty. Taiwan Style Rice Wrapped was just average.  I was quite happy with the breakfast at Yi Mei. Pretty sure I will return next time and try out more of their other dishes.

NB5XBxBBcphhKWp7LusuQQ.text: Hello 626. I missed you, my Taiwanese breakfast. I sat down alone, because my Taiwanese friend is never available, and ordered my favorite breakfast: an order of sugar spiked soy milk, fan tuan (salty,) beef roll, and an order of juicy steamed juicy pork dumplings. I don't eat this much, so I save the rest for later.  This place is always serving tasty and freshly made food. The service is good and the location is perfect. The prices were about the same as Cali's branch. It was all about $22.

eAE_0hRky_dFLy-M1DYA1Q.text: My review is for their service, which deserves 1 star. I've came with 3 other friends and they said you can't certain foods. Then the tables next to us and behind us got to order those food for breakfast. Either they're racist or whatnot, I didn't appreciate their service and their rude attitude. That's why I don't like mainland Chinese people, rude as hell.

IhsgVjjjTdiL6bnvutzHMw.text: Taiwanese style breakfast in Vegas what else can you expect?  A piece of my hometown food at way cheaper than tourist food on the stripe?! I take two!!  Came here on the most crowded days- Christmas weekend, ladies in the house were in commend and obviously in good mood.  Saw them giving kids rice cracker cookies, one big package per child- well Merry Christmas and here is when you say the reason you love Taiwanese people:).   Packed house and yet very efficient.  One tradition about Chinese dinning is that you need to be able to stand other guests staring at you and giving you a very clear hint of hurry up that we want to sit down look.  Don't be offended, that's part of the culture.  You gotta not be shy and be flexible in the seating, that could range from share table to servers bussing your table so quickly that you get that you can't hang out and take your time.  In our case, we are two people so the best chance to grab a quick bite is to let them know we are willing to share table.  Both days we waited for less than 5 minutes.  Oh, and politeness always work in your favor, I smile and wish them Merry Christmas, got the tables ahead of whole grumpy bunch who complaint that they waited 30 minutes.    We order all the vegetarian spread, ranging from soy milk (comes plain, sugar bottle on the table for customized sweetness), Chinese donut ,classic rice ball, vege bun, egg pancake, second day I had porridge with some classic tapas like fermented tofu cube and cucumber salad.  Hit the spot, nothing extraordinary but everything nostalgic.  I can't really complaint when my homies open the doors at 7am to serve these massive crazy amount of hungry people.  I am grateful for these hard working servers and cooks and looking forward for this classic ritual again next time when I am in Vegas!

Kjw7a7qQodllfP1a0GEgwQ.text: It was Sunday and we were coming off our high of an exciting and fun weekend in Vegas.  It only seemed appropriate for us to "sober up" with some traditional Taiwanese breakfast foods.  The place was slightly out of the way but we were still up and at 'em early enough to avoid those who waiting until check-out time to run for the CA border.  It wasn't busy which was a relief (possibly due to its location) and when we walked in, we were promptly given a clean and spacious table.  The restaurant isn't big but it wasn't crowded either.  We ended up ordering a bunch of stuff.  The best of which were: Egg cake with Chinese donut - we thought the egg cake would be wrapped around one Chinese donut but it was two.  Massive!  and we ordered 3 of them!! Taiwan-style stir fried rice noodles - topped with a meat sauce...totally reminded me of home. Stinky tofu - not too stinky but the garlic soy sauce paste they serve with it was so yummy, the tofu ended up being a vehicle for the soy sauce instead of the other way around. Tofu custard soup (salty) - looks almost like a hot and sour soup.  some people might find it bland but I couldn't get enough of it Cold soybean milk - very fresh and tasty, natural  The not as impressive: Oyster pancake - I noticed they used clams.  CLAMS!  That's very different from oysters and make the pancake very terrible.  The sauce they used was also too sweet. Taiwan-style "meat ball" - this is really some ground up meat and bamboo shoots inside a skin made of rice flour so it's chewier.  Texturally, it was good.  The meat itself was seasoned well.  Unfortunately, they used the same sauce on it as on the oyster pancake - too sweet! Steam pork/veggie bun - I didn't personally try this but my friends said it was dry. Milk tea - they used some wierd condensed milk which threw off the taste of the tea and it was further ruined by the fact they didn't use Taiwanese black tea (red tea in Chinese).  Service was very good and friendly with the owner/lady coming over to chat with us briefly.  We thanked them a lot and they thanked us a lot and in the end, everyone was happy.  I hope we can make this a Vegas tradition!

5XDpIAI4o-1nX2AeoJzh5g.text: This is as authentic as you'll get for Taiwanese food in America.  Stinky tofu, Ba-Won, Oah Jen, Paigu Fun, mmmm of course they serve the breakfast stuff, but expect to get here earlier to get the food.  It's Sunday, and they started telling new customers that they are closing at around 1:30pm due to selling out of food.  Unexpected, and it is what it is... authentic Taiwanese.  Be vocal and be forward or else you're not eating much.

TPEbd1QrkM60Obuuy9dDFA.text: Best chinese breakfast restaurant in town, a lot of LA visiter come with bus load. Also has dinner items  choice.noodle or rice soup.

2LOf7tBOBIe97eNuHYDskA.text: Excellent, tasty, authentic. Nice staff and clean. Opens early which suits us early risers. Definitely recommend this place to people looking for an alternative to dim sum breakfast.

G7aLfpJWI8E4sK5Ik1k1VQ.text: So far been to Vegas twice and visited Yi Mei three times for breakfast! It's rare to see a place that serves Taiwanese breakfast at 7:00AM everyday throughout the week... as least not many places like that on the east coast. In terms of quality, the FOOD IS GREAT! It also has a great variety of Taiwanese items. My favorite are there rice rolls. And yes, plural, because there are FIVE different kind of rice rolls! Yi Mei and Champion Rice Rolls are the best! Everything we tried were pretty good... steam pork & veg bun, sweet bean curd, radish bun, Taiwanese meat ball, and leek dumplings. We had a variety of steam buns to go... and all of them were great! Pork and Mushroom and Vegetarian are must tries! Really like how they had sweet cold soil milk readily available - taste great!  Didn't try any of the non-breakfast stuff probably because the breakfast were sooo good, but I'm sure the other items are just as excellent. In general, the price is a little on the high side for Taiwanese food, but it's worth it! Really would like to try the pork chop rice next time.

oCtqatQtHym7QIV_KVPnxA.text: As a Taiwanese I can say this place is as authentic as you can get around here! The servers are very friendly all the time and their food always bring comfort and joy to me! Love their tendon and beef noodle soups, the tendon they make is just out of this would. Another of our must-order is egg pancake (traditional Taiwanese breakfast) and stinky tofu with Taiwanese kimchi on the side. After we finished all these, we ordered two more steam pork and vegetables buns and a YiMei rice roll to-go for our road. If you want to try authentic Taiwanese food, feel free to follow what I ordered. You won't be disappointed !
