voc_pfqNM3glTPO9fLxZcg.text: This is probably the best Chinese food around here. Everything on the menu is authentic and I oh have been to Taiwan or southern part of China then you will know it is soooooo gooood.  We ordered classical Taiwan noodle soup and xiaolongbao at dine in. To be honest I think I should have ordered the tender version of beef noodle soup because the meat is kinda hard to chew, however the noodle and the soup are just sooooo good. It uses the original broth from beef soup and unlike other Chinese restaurants they put little salt and it's much healthier. They also have the bok choy in the soup which you know is typical and good. Xiaolongbao is more southern taste like Shanghai and it is as good if not better than dingtaifeng  After this extraordinary food experience we then ordered more to go so that next morning we wouldn't be starving. We ordered Taiwan sausage rice -- turns out to be soooo good that we finished most of it before the picture. It has eggs and Taiwanese sausage, side vegetable and braised egg on top of the rice. So gooooood.  We also ordered onion Chinese pancake and egg, shaobing and egg, and stinky tofu.  One thing to note is that we should be ordering only one of the pancake and egg, because we were too full in the morning and could not finish all.  The other thing to notice is that stinky tofu is a must try here. I don't see any other restaurants have authentic ones, this one has it and it is more Shanghai style, crispy on the outside and soft in the inside, alone side the provided pickled vegetable and the garlic onion sauce, it is just extraordinary and tasty.  I rated five stars based on the food quality and the satisfactory I had and my wife had.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our friend eating the takeouts
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The only thing left for sausage rice when I realized I should have take a pic
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States

eg_Mp_pH24yYdWSAv2BxZg.text: 100% best bowl of   beef noodle outside Taipei. The owner Bo is an awesome individual who makes you feel at home. Everything is handmade and is just like being back in Taiwan.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UmnL_ywULwuYyDV2AlCjQQ.text: I was ecstatic to find Taiwanese breakfast in Las Vegas since we don't have very good Taiwanese breakfast options in the Bay Area. The Yi Mei is very different from the Yi Mei in Rowland Heights so I assume that this is also a brandname pirate. The customer service offers typical Chinese brusqueness, but they provide the necessities as required. We really enjoyed the breakfast items - the salty rice roll (chinese donut and pork sung wrapped in glutinous rice), egg pancake (their egg was thick and fluffy), soy milk, turnip cake (each plate comes with two thick pieces) and beef scallion roll (the roll was very pale and bland - least favourite item). We also tried their beef noodle soup (clear soup version), oyster pancake (decent, but can't compare to Taiwan's...) and stinky tofu (aka stinking tofu on the menu). My favourite lunch item was the stinky tofu with pickled cabbage. I also suggest checking out the cold dish items. We tried the mini dried fish with tofu and beef tendon, which were both very tasty and had a good kick to them. I highly recommend this as a day after meal!

Ek3n0wcdLR5zJUuM_qnupw.text: Two visits, one on 12/18/16 and one on 12/20/16:  This place was recommended to me by Taiwanese restaurant owners who used to live in Vegas and have since relocated to New Mexico to open up Chinese and Taiwanese places in Santa Fe and Albuquerque near me.  Delicious and authentic with a good menu selection. The first time here I got the green onion pancake with egg, jook, and three cup chicken over rice. It also comes with a little bit of vegetables and an egg. The second time I got the green onion pancake and an order of fried rice noodles with meat sauce and egg. My mom tried the rice noodles and approved.  Only reason I can't give it five stars is because the food is too salty. A solid place overall.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Half of a green onion pancake with egg and three cup chicken, also with an egg.

KI-uM1Y7lFC11NANWtUNOw.text: No less than fantastic.  Better than virtually all pan-asian places around.  We are rushing for airport and the owner priotized our order and the taste is more than satisfactory.  Double thumb up.

TgCMHwOjYvU1ptOPw0WjRw.text: Good place for breakfast. Came twice! If you prefer to take some jot dishes, this place can warm your stomach. They fresh make their majority food. A good place to try traditional Chinese breakfast but not the best!

ZN0TSGTz2pZWBL85m6lT0g.text: Best Taiwanese food I have ever had across the U.S. Speaking of a man (and a decent cook) born and raised in Taiwan and has been living in the U.S. for eight years. Hell yeah.   Definitely try the beef noodle soup, sticky rice ball, and fried pork chop rice dish. You'd regret if you don't.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Taiwanese style grilled pork chop.

RgxxE59rh-0uWGVH2fh-Bw.text: Went there with my friends for breakfast. Taiwanese food is not their only serving food, they also have other Chinese food (but not as good as other restaurant). Yes they have a lot of options, and the price is very nice, so it is a good place to eat for breakfast or for people who wanna try different traditional Taiwanese food. (I ordered the noodle, I think it is just OK but my bf likes it a lot)

S8A2MOqieSIL96LGsHGOcA.text: Overall I like this place and will come back.   Service:  2 stars. They weren't rude or anything, except this one lady who was too busy to answer my question, but you have to go to the front to order and pay or you will wait forever for them to come to your table. Also don't expect them to be nice and patient. You better be ready to go with minimal questions.    Food:  Salted bean curd:  5 stars. Really interesting. It's salty tofu pudding with a savory broth and chinese donut. Will order it again and it was only 3 bucks  Yi mei rice roll:  4. Pretty decent. I think it needs more kimchee in it. basically it's a sticky rice roll with a fried chinese donut, kimchee and savory pork shreds. A staple breakfast item in Taiwan.   Beef roll:  3 stars. I really liked the cucumbers and kimchee that came with it. 5 stars for the side dishes. But the beef roll itself wasn't that good. The green onion pancakes it was rolled in was super chewy and flavorless. Not flaky crunchy and savory like it's supposed to be. Also the beef is tendonous, which adds to the chewiness. There's no sauce or in the rolls. Usually there's a sweet hoisin sauce but this one doesn't have any.   Shanghai dumplings:  2 stars. It's very different. Some of the skin breaks so all the juices leak out before you even touch it. I would say at least 3 out of the 8 had no juice. The ones with the juice/soup tastes different from the more traditional Shanghai dumplings. This one seems to have a very strong pork and soy sauce flavor but that's about it. Wouldn't order it again.   I gave it 4 stars because I do want to come back to try other things and I think that this place is a really good deal. All the food listed came it to 22 dollars and the two of us were very very full. Also once you order, food comes hella quick!

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salted bean curd. Awesome!!
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shao long bao. Not that great

pY4giuK9dtajffXUgixcRQ.text: Pretty authentic Taiwanese style breakfast. Dishes are tasty and my soy milk was warm just the way I like. It was busy early in the morning so make sure you wake up early!!

T0KpseQuXKQ9I4JrMv44Dw.text: This is my daily breakfast for whole week during CES 2019Do not miss it the breakfast only from 7-9.30,do not be later

OEjEF5D2Kl-to0XUwXQFQQ.text: What a fun food find!!  Are there places like this in SoCal? If so where are they and why haven't I discovered them yet.   It was cold and pouring rain outside. Errant summer storm in Las Vegas. I scurried in from the parking lot and it was so nice to have an order of freshly made soy milk plopped down in front of me. Odd that it was served in a big soup bowl but it was piping hot and fragrant and i didn't hesitate to try it. I added some sugar to it as directed by the waitress and drank it like soup with my fat Chinese spoon. Wonder why they don't serve it in a cup or mug? Oh well if this is how they do it in Taiwan then this is how I'll do it here.   Choices, choices, so many choices. I had the worst time trying to decide what to order. Everything sounded so promising and fun. Yelp photos helped me settle on the spicy beef noodle soup but I added a twist and ordered the one that had tendons in it and I am glad I did.  Forget bone marrow it's all about tendons! I love the melt in your mouth texture. I googled tendon nutritional value and found that tendons are high in protein, collagen and are 99% fat free.  Choo chooo put me on the Tendon Train. Delicious.  I also had the temple meatball which was really flavorful and had a fantastic texture. Highly recommend that dish. The only dish I wasn't very fond of was the rice ball roll thing(sorry don't know names) I asked for something to go that was easy to eat while driving and the waitress recommended it. It was also something I saw a photo of on yelp and people seemed to enjoy it but I found it unhealthy tasting. Everything I ate up to that point tasted clean and healthy but this had fried components that made me feel bad about myself afterwards.  Bummer. I still give the place 5 stars for everything else.  I can't help it if my palate seems adverse to fried food. Others seem to enjoy the fried stuff just fine.

j8NabhiOG-rBw1zY6VSaRA.text: Went there for Taiwanese style breakfast with high hopes, ordered some usual brekkie items such as pancake and donut, beef roll, savory soy milk, and rice roll. The flavors were right on, but the restaurant didn't seem to care enough to make the dishes more enjoyable; the soy milk was lukewarm, the beef roll was dry from sitting out for too long, and the donut was way too greasy. This place could have easily been much better, they just didn't care.

0hTOmDmsmhC-yP2S3esQQg.text: After 6 days of road trip with Continental and American breakfast, This place is like a breath of fresh air! The beef noodle soup is bit spicy, noodle is too soft for my taste. But everything else is right on. Normally, I would give it a 3 star but judging from the circumstance and it's Vegas, I gave it a 4.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Taiwanese Breakfast!

1df8475CPaWdAG45MCL4Lg.text: We missed the owner. When she was here, the service was great. This time the server comment my husband not to order everything at one time. Come on, we just add one drink at the end of the ordering. She may act nicer if you speak English.

JR00N6c-QyimB9i8PM1MPQ.text: I'd like to come here for breakfast once in a while. I speak fluently in Chinese, so there wouldn't be any language barrier. The service used to be ok, since the owner who is a really nice Taiwanese lady served me couple time. However, this time when I went there was HORRIBLE! The first second I walked into the restaurant, there was another Taiwanese elderly lady standing behind the cashier. She was staring at me without any welcoming smile when I was walking to her. When I was standing right in front of her, she didn't greet with me and kinda waiting for me to greet with her. And she gave me a really irritating face! Then she lift up her chin a little bit and blinked in the most annoying way I've ever seen. Ok, I ignored that. Then I told her what I wanted to order for to-go. Then, there's another young male customer came to the cashier and asked for a check. She gave him a very bright smile and called him "handsome boy" in Chinese and finished his transaction before me. Really! The guy came after me!!!!!  Ok, I ignored that too. When she handled me my food, she said "shiiiit!" In English. She said it really loud. I didn't really know if she was saying that to me or for something else, but it's still rude to curse in front of a customer. She is definitely the rudest and the most miserable person I've ever met in my entire life. I didn't do anything or showed any disrespect to her from the very beginning to the end. I even said "thank you" after all of this. Btw, last time me and my bf were there for breakfast, they undercooked the wonton. And it smelled wired.  I will NEVER put my feet in this restaurant, and I don't recommend this place to any of you. If you love your life, stay away from this place!!!!

lHcL09La7sA9S5a0MA9YQQ.text: With our schedules often in conflict, my mom and I rarely get to eat meals together. Some planets aligned, call it fate, whatever. We finally had the opportunity to have a late Saturday lunch together, courtesy of this Taiwanese deli. Initially, we were going off of her dim sum craving, but decided to try something different. *cue my devious plan to suggest one of my many Yelp bookmarks*  After browsing the menu for a few minutes, we decided on the pork chop rice and the three cup chicken rice. Didn't take very long to get our food and man, their portions are HUGE. One of our entrees could've fed two or three people, so you should either come famished or bring a friend! We ended up splitting the crispy fried pork chop and taking the other entree home. Both dishes had their respective meats, some steamed or blanched vegetables, a large helping of rice, and a soy sauce egg. Mmm, did that meal hit the spot or what?  Service was courteous and friendly, but you may have to get your own napkins and water. If you're afraid of language barriers, it turns out some of them speak English, so no fear! My mom and I speak a lesser known dialect, but we managed with the Mandarin we knew. Also, you're probably better off bringing cash to pay the bill, but most Asian establishments are like that.  Definitely want to try their other offerings, especially their breakfast items and noodle soups.

qW8c8BY7F4eIkiGeQiDDAw.text: Browsed Yelp for places that serves breakfast at 8am other than fast food and we came here.  Authentic Taiwanese food with a good variety.  All we ordered tasted good; beef noodles, radish cake, you tiao and Xiao Long Bao.  The staff are also very friendly and welcoming!  Recommended when you have Chinese food crave!

YXQxSZq44HdoCm9BsGYLOQ.text: Learned about this restaurant via yelp.  Decided to give it a try at their Taiwanese breakfast.  We ordered their soya bean juice (served hot in a big bowl) unsweetened, got some Chinese doughnuts for dunking, different Taiwanese pastries and steamed rice dumplings.  It was an interesting breakfast.  Wait staff needs to learn how to speak English.  It was a little difficult talking to the wait staff.    It was just an OK breakfast.

9PkPLtlJfMxRQYbI2-Isvg.text: This place is close to the strip and has amazing Taiwanese breakfast.   They serve fresh unsweetened soy milk, and yummy rice ball. One would think deep-fried Chinese donuts would be good, right? But nope, they may be fried in old oil. Here, they have fresh oil! The deep-fried donuts are crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside.   Next time I am in Vegas, I will most def swing by for breakfast.   Plus, for 2 people, my bill came out to be less than $12.

_8TlSPlBu-hb6zTu9SGWIg.text: AMAZING FOOD!!!   The most authentic Taiwanese food I have had since visiting Taiwan!   Breakfast and lunch specialties that can't be found anywhere else in Vegas!   My mother-in-law is from Taiwan and this is her favorite restaurant when she comes into town.   The spicy beef noodle soup is a must have when you come here! The portions are large so I usually share with my wife. Everything is made fresh to order, and they have a huge selections of dishes.   Some of our other favorites include: spicy wanton soup fried onion pancake turnip cake with a fried egg on top (Luo Buo Gao) Pork and mushroom steamed buns Curry meat pies Sun cakes Soy bean milk (made fresh daily) rice roll (fan tuan) twisted cruller (you tiao) Baked wheat cake (shao bing) Fried pot stickers And several more that I can't remember right now  A MUST TRY FOR ANY ASIAN FOOD LOVER!!!

z78hql6i0rAhP_ouU9PB7Q.text: The service here is non existent and rude. We can't speak for the food as we ended up leaving. If you come here, it's better to order takeout or else you will be waiting forever.

k-UyULFUxrH9cqGPIucKDA.text: Worse service ever!! The waitress sent the wrong food and drinks even we had been waiting for 2 hrs for our order. After all the long waiting, of course we had to wait for the check, wait to pay, the waitress told us we supposedly to pay 18% of tips! WTF! Won't visit this restaurant ever again!

89C9i1a0OFxJn7qFwEv-gQ.text: The food is awesome, but the customer service is not that great. I guess it is their culture. If you are looking for good authentic Taiwanese food, this is the place to go to, but don't expect a highly attentive staff to serve you. I've been to the other Taiwanese restaurants in Chinatown, but so far, this deli has better customer service than those ones. At least the staff here smiles at you, for me that's friendly enough.

oy-Q2N55N2aJ1KxCic2UFA.text: I had the fan tuan (rice ball) and love it! The fried Chinese "donut" was crispy and fragrant. They don't skimp on the pork floss and the rice was just the right texture, not too hard, but solid enough to maintain structural integrity and offering the perfect level of chewiness. The fan tuan here was WAY better than the one from their LA store.  I also had the beef shao bing (sandwich-like thing). I was caught off guard that it came cold. I mean, I get that it's prepared but couldn't they at least serve it lukewarm? or room temp? I couldn't eat it cold so I had the waitress reheat it for me.   After the reheating, it was pretty good, but but blow-my-mind spectacular. The dough was crispy and the beef was okay.   The douhua (soy...jelly?) was very refreshing. I love that it was not too sweet and you can add sugar to your liking.  Get the fan tuan.

photos.caption: Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Duohua in front. Fan tuan on right. Beef sandwich on left. doujiang in the back.
Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fan Tuan/Rice ball. A Must-try. Seriously

EhUqOhXtaolGNCzBYlrxTQ.text: The food is really good but the service is terrible. We waited for a long time and when we tried to get the menu by ourself, the service lady yelled at us. It is the first time that I have such experience. If you really want the food, just order take out. This is my sincere advice.

ExrdNiyBgKPjJlddvNYqsg.text: I am so happy found this place!  Great food - I have not had something that I would not have again.  Some of my favorite (very traditional): --Sweet soy bean milk (you need to add sugar to it yourself) --Chinese donut --Man-Tou (white steamed buns - no filling)  I agree with the other reviewer - do not expect good service.  Great food though - so yes, I am a fan!

ZrKCkqELnLttIjdbO1OSyA.text: I love their spicy beef and tendon noodle soup. It comes in this bowl that looks small in circumference but is deep, so it's a lot of food. The noodles are cooked just right, beef could be a bit softer, but there's very little fat in it, and the broth is hot and spicy. There's only a few places I go in town to get my beef noodle fix, and this is on the top of my list. If you don't speak Mandarin or look Chinese, I find that they tend to make the soup less spicy because they don't think you can handle it, so ask the waitress to make the soup super spicy.  They have a wide variety of Taiwanese dishes, ranging from breakfast to lunch items. I haven't tried their breakfast, so I can't comment on it. But they do have the typical Taiwanese appetizers and dishes, such as pig's ear, oyster pancake, and pork chop rice. The only dish I'm not a fan of is the noodles with the spicy peanut sauce, only because it tastes like peanut butter and chili garlic sauce mixed together.   Service is on the lackluster side, they like to assume that if you look Chinese, you must be able to speak Mandarin and nothing else (like Cantonese). If you want water, you have to go to the water dispenser to get some. There's usually only one waitress working, so if you don't want to wait to pay for your bill, it's better to just go up to the register and do it. Also, there's a minimum $10 order if you're using a debit or credit card.   Overall, Yi Mei has some great Taiwanese food but their service could use some improvement.

3-x8Yllfd29UA5TXph2EPQ.text: I have been a regular there since they are the only one that has authentic Taiwanese style food. But I gotta say that they really don't have any service there and the quality is good is never consistent. The server there is always rude even if you speak Chinese. My girl friend and I have been really upset about their service not only once. They really need to work on a lot of things to survive in the industry.

RBf5-O6fmJ9uegFG9J7mOQ.text: There are absolutely zero Chinese breakfast places in Colorado (where I live) other than dim sum. My excitement was overwhelming when I saw the variety of dishes being offered at Yi Mei: salty tofu brain, you tiao, dumplings, pickled veggies, etc. My husband and I decided on soup dumplings, stinky tofu, and some veggies. The flavors were good; albeit a little oily and salty for us. Soup dumplings were almost on point but had no soup inside. We will definitely come back here when we're back in Vegas.

rwTj8h6O0rBCjaD-F4MvNw.text: Mmmmmmm.  Traditional Taiwanese breakfast in Vegas.  Good food for the price.  Portion is decent, and the dining area is clean and neat.  Huge parking lot, and plenty of parking.  Service is okay.  Well worth to stop by if you are around the hood and are willing to try something else other than ordinary American breakfast in Vegas.

Ako6zFAKYeyxXUdShmlzqA.text: This place was the highlight of my trip. Got there around 9:30 am on Tuesday. We had the salted soy milk with Chinese donut, sliced beef sandwich, and fried pork with rice. The first 2 were just average, but the fried pork and rice dish was fantastic! Big enough to feed 2 people, the pork was flavorful, moist, and crisp, came with kimchi, preserved mustard greens, bok choi, and minced pork over white rice. Best fried pork chop ever. Will definitely go back when I'm in Vegas. I found the service to be fine. They're Taiwanese and don't greet you when you enter, which is fine 'cause I'm typically a grouch in the morning. I just asked a server if we could sit anywhere and got an affirmative. Menus are already on the tables and they're efficient in taking your order and bringing hot food. Pay at the counter. What else do you want from a mom and pop? We weren't charged tip automatically for our party of 3 - could be 'cause we paid cash and didn't really expect that much service. They're busy enough as it is without 4+ stars on yelp, so hopefully y'all will continue to rate it poorly so that it's easy to get a seat when I visit in future.

61ZAzrB8fhS3iPcVanyOKw.text: Service has gotten better and it seems like management has changed hands.  The authenticity of Taiwanese breakfast here is unmatched.  Upgrading to 4 starts,  but you have to like this sort of food.

yt5Wr3-hbCCP3chWPkITeQ.text: It's hard to find some good Taiwanese food in Las Vegas. I come here often with my parents because they miss eating food from their homeland. The food is usually bland, but sometimes it's okay. I guess it depends on the chef. The oyster omelet is fairly bland, even with the sauce on top. Most of the time the oysters are only half cooked. The stinky tofu is nothing special. It just tastes like fried tofu. The spicy beef soup and the pork chop rice are the only things I like to get from there because everything else is bland or super bland.

nygO6DFZmREWUhkGTjPr2A.text: They have very interesting menu items that I have not seen in Hawaii so had to try.  First off was Duck Tongue, which was the best dish we had.  Had that 5 spice taste but was very mild, which I liked.  It was served cold , tender meat but watch out for the cartilage.  Next was the Stinky Fried Tofu.   It was OK and it does smell like an old sock.  Next "Spicy" Beef Noodle, I put the quotes because it was not spicy at all.  Noodles had a nice chew to it, nice beefy flavor from the soup,  big chunks of beef and tendon.  Overall it was a nice dish but wanted it SPICY.  Lastly we had the Shiao Long Bao.  First time eating it so have no reference point.  It's OK, wish the dipping sauce had a little more vinegar to it.  Not sure if our next Vegas trip we'll go here again.  If we did I'd definitely order the duck tongue again and probably try other item.

HIPAHdeGLZX_QQZo8y-uHg.text: The best beef noodles outside of Taiwan and even better than some of the average beef noodle joints on the island. The nut milks and morning breakfast options are also amazing. Would happily make a trip out to Vegas just for the food here! Simply delicious and worth the journey!

tBOwoFPXOY5DCG-dFESIbA.text: I come here for the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup. It's flavor is fairly close to a famous place that has been around for ages in Ximen, Taipei.  Visually, the soup looks thin, but all the flavor is there.  There are veggies (baby bok choy) and healthy chunks of flavorful meat and tendon in the bowl. I usually get it without the shredded pickles, since I'm not a fan of pickles.  All the other food that I've tried is ok to good.  But if I'm coming here, it's for that Spicy Beef Noodle Soup.

ennOJsrpz87rQ3p5ARaXCA.text: I'm sick, its raining, and all i kept thinking was the spicy beef noodle soup that Teri C. praised about in her review.  I remember clearly she stated that "This IS the thing to order at Yi Mei," and at last I'm a believer!  For $6.99 you get a hearty bowl of noodle soup with a kick.  Modest plumped egg noodles perched high above the broth like a volcano with diced mustard leaf and sliced baby bok choy acting the role as lava.  Only, those greens aren't just for textures.  Scallions and cilantro are thrown into the fire as well. The soup itself has a really nice tang in there for a spicy broth not to mentions there's plenty of tender loving' beef chunks swimming around in your oasis. Perfect therapy food for the unwell.  Make sure you grab yourself a Chrysanthemum Tea while you wait for your remedy.    I tried their XLB  (Shanghai Dumplings) and didn't really enjoy them as much i wanted to.  They were mini size dumplings, so there wasn't much juice in them.  And because of their size you'd know they're made in-house.  The soy dipping sauce that came with it was mild in sweet with shredded ginger slice.  I add vinegar, chili paste, and soy for personal preference which prob made it worse.  15min wait for these.    Green Scallion Pancakes were also tested since my Taiwanese food's archives is limit close to nothing.   They were a bit bland since it was thick and way doughier than what I'm use to.  Sadly, I couldn't take more than a few bite of this.   Sorry, no pics. I've been here three times this week and each time I castled myself away from everything that's bind to me with that first sip.  Luckily for me an order of the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup is not super, ginormous since i magically tend to slip off layers of clothing during my treatment.  So might i suggest taking off your jacket before digging in?  If you're confused about which store it is, it's the store 2-3 doors down from 168 Market with only Chinese characters surrounding "Taiwan Deli."  Upon entering you can order either at counter or grab a seat and wait for service.  Either way the attention you receive will have curative qualities.

do1xc7n_b0svLqjxsxzcvQ.text: We were fans of the Champion Gourmet on Spring Mountain and very sad when they closed down.  However, the Yangs (Bobby and Misti) were the first to tell us that they were reopening business in this shopping center and we anxiously awaited their grand opening.    What we loved most was their hot pot option - something that currently is not offered.  (Word from Auntie Bo directly said she'll be starting the hot pot business again come the new year! Yay!)  We even missed out on the famous CMYE: Breakfast of Champions event, which got raving reviews and reinforced how fabulous the Taiwanese breakfast experience was there.  (We plan on hitting it up one of these days!)  One day the Husband came home and said he wanted some Spicy Beef Noodle Soup from Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli. Apparently someone from work had been raving about it, and yelpers concurred!  So off we went to dinner!  This is what we tried:     * Spicy Beef Noodle Soup ($6.99) - This is THE thing to order at Yi Mei.  Look around and you'll see every table have a bowl of this.  Every review talks about it and I can see why.  The Husband liked it and found the beef to be tender.  I was personally enjoying the noodle part more.  It had a good texture, something that Suki L. talks extensively about it in her review.  It also came with bok chopy and pickles, be sure to ask for more of those preserved pickles because they add a nice contrast to the dish.  Bring me a bowl of the noodles, broth, bok choy, and pickles and I'm good to go!   * Special Fry Tofu ($4.99) - This was a long shot because we weren't sure exactly what was going to make this a 'special' fried tofu.  While we waited for this dish to arrive, the Husband asked if they had the stinky tofu still.  I wasn't sure since there was another dish on the menu called "Hot Spicy Special Tofu" and thought that may be the dish!  When it did come, it looked like before with pickled cabbage and a dipping sauce.  When I bit into it, it was definitely the stinky tofu.  The texture was a bit dried out, but the crispiness of the tofu was refreshing.  * Green Onion Pancake ($2.99) - One pancake arrived and it was a bit thicker than what I'm used to getting. We needed to add some hot chili oil (and other condiments found on the table) to give it a little more of a kick.  I personally prefer thinner green onion pancakes.  * Steamed Bao ($4.99) - Also known as Shanghai dumplings or  Xiao Lung Baos.  They were the last to arrive.  There were eight small dumplings that were a little gummy and could have used a bit more time in the steamer.  I prefer it that way so the hot soup within the dumpling can burn my tongue a bit.  This is a pretty casual restaurant where there is a self service station for hot tea, water, and utensils.  You'll find this on your immediate right when you walk in.  Take a seat and be sure they know you sat down so you'll get menus.  (Try to ignore the spelling errors on the menu.) And when you're ready to pay, head to the register and know what number table you sat on to help them out.  This place is steadily busy, and not just from new customers who happen to be shopping at the nearby 168 Market.  But rather, these are long-time customers from their old restaurant.  You can tell they have a strong following.  When the Husband was paying, he got a chance to meet and talk with Auntie Bo, who is just the friendliest lady.  That's when we heard that hot pot was returning come the new year and we were psyched!  You can't help but love the family-oriented atmosphere where regulars come to enjoy some quality homelike food.  She really makes an effort to know her customers!     Not only is Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli a restaurant, but it's a mini market as well. You'll find dried goods and refrigerated items for sale.  Take a look around for some interesting and unique goods!  Update! 01.06.11 - I stopped by and asked Auntie Bo about the return of the hot pot. Looks like it's not going to happen anymore. =(  She said they just don't have the staff to do it.  Oh well.  But she did mention Dragon House as an option for hot pot which I can confirm!

rmOK1z4L1nLsujagDrUB1A.text: I wasn't super impressed with this place.   Based on reviews and word of mouth, I was excited to try given the lack of good Taiwanese food in town. I got my group together and we headed over.  Well, I was pretty disappointed by the selection of menu items and found it hard to read. I'm used to misspellings, grammar error and non-translated verbiage... but this was ridiculous. My whole party had a tough time navigating our way through the menu, even my friend who knows Taiwanese.   When we finally decided what we wanted and ordered, we were excited about our meals coming out. I have to say, I was pretty disappointed. I did enjoy some of the food we had ordered, but a majority of it was bland. I didn't feel the need to lick my plate and that makes me sad. I needed more spice or flavor to almost everything I ordered and the textures were a little off as well.  I left feeling hungry and unfulfilled, as did the rest of my party.

29jhqufPKdkPu-MKyIXKUA.text: I didn't interact here as much as I usually would because they're very Asian here. My mom brought me here and she did the ordering, all of it. I was also on the phone so I didn't witness much in the beginning.  I've grown up with oil sticks so this was a pretty awesome place for me to go to. Usually I'd eat oil sticks and fried taro and the like in China or New York or something.  We ordered a breakfast meal pretty much. It was just veggie-pork bun and oil sticks and this sweet soupy stuff. I totally forgot the name. If you look at the menu, everything looks cheap. It's about $1-4 range (the menu on the wall). I'm probably going to come here a lot with friends now and get random stuff here and there. It's as close as I've been to to the food that I grew up eating for breakfast.  I'll be back for sure!

FqvnFc4trteP_1AGu72Rdg.text: We ( My date and I ) checked out this newly opened Taiwanese Deli place that's next to Lelysee Bakery and near 168 Market.  Reminds me of Tea Planet without the booth seats and colorful interior. They have some snacks and health products for sale that you can browse through if you like..  They have a self serve utensils and water dispenser if you need an extra bowl or cup to share food or just to drink plain water.  We ordered the Chrysanthemum Tea, which was delightfully refreshing to taste. I could drink 10 of these if there were refills.. but that's just wishful thinking. This is my all time summer drink to cool my body when I feel like I'm about to experience heat exhaustion... it works instantly and you literally feel relieved.. even to say... Aaaaaaaaaaah!!  For dinner, we ordered two most popular Taiwanese dishes:  Spicy Beef Noodle (Soup) - Surprised it wasn't overpowering with the spices that I thought it would have. It was actually just right in giving it a kick each time you took a sip. I actually really enjoyed this broth. I loved the noodles! It had a great texture as if it was homemade. Thicker than fettuccine noodles, but thinner width-wise. It was like udon noodles texture, but half its size... absolutely enjoyed every bite. The beef was like stew meat that is cooked for many hours... unfortunately I had to minus a star for the fact that some of the chunks of meat ( the ends/corners of it ) were quite tough to chew upon. And for that reason, I couldn't even eat the remainder of the beef chunks, but I did finish all the noodles, sliced green cabbage, and some kind of pickled shredded mustard green.  Rice with Pork Chop - It also came with a boiled egg, steam greens, and ground pork. The coating is somewhat similar to katsu style, but this batter they dip the pork chop into and deep fry is on point! It had a light, airy crispy crunch on the outside.. which was my favorite!!! * My eyes lit up like Christmas lights in full blast from biting into a piece. Very tasty and satisfied all my taste buds. Even the meat was tender and juicy.  Bravo!! Bravooooo!!! I definitely recommend this dish if you love meat and deep fried food. It really hits the spot indefinitely :)  They also open at 7a.m.- 11:30a.m. for breakfast, which I heard was incredibly cheap, but good. Service was quick, but not much smiles... At least my tummy was smiling and it put me in a great mood. Hey I'm an emotional eater... What? *Ladeedadee skipping away.....

MQIeMy9HtUZL0Euv90cfiw.text: Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli has finally opened just a few doors down from 168 Supermarket. And on its first day being opened to the public, it has already attracted a very nice crowd of eager patrons.  From the hand written signs near the cashiers counter, it states that it is open everyday except Thursday. This little restaurant with seating capacity of 48 has a Breakfast Menu which is served from 7am to 11:30am, and a Lunch Menu served from 11:30am to 9pm. Since I was coming from work, by the time I had arrived it was already 11:36am and most of their breakfast items were sold out. Meaning no freshly made soy milk (or Iced Soy/Bean Juice as it is called in their menu) for me, which was the primary objective of this visit and the reason for skipping the free lunch at work. So I ordered the Beef Roll with Preserved Vegetable (it was that or the version made with pork), which was pretty much the only item available from the Breakfast Menu. And it was quickly served to me on a red china and still wrapped in the plastic wrap.  It is a sesame crusted thin bread stuffed with slices of braised beef with Chinese preserved vegetable.  It was alright. A little on the dry side, but a good experience to try their version thousands of miles away from the original in Taiwan and China.  As I ate and looking over their menu I see that they also serve various handmade dumplings (such as "Steam Bao" aka Xiao Long Bao, which was also sold out), Spicy Beef Noodle (which I ordered), various Taiwanese Deli, Shaved Ice (which they don't currently serve), cold beverages and hot desserts. The back of their business cards also states in Chinese that they served Taiwanese style hot pots, but that is not in their menu, just like the breakfastitems are not listed in the menu. I also ordered "Temple Meatball" and Fish-Ball Soup (should be more accurately called Fuzhou fish ball).  The first item I ordered arrived quickly, since it was premade and came on a plate still wrapped in plastic wrap.  It was okay, maybe too dried and lack much flavor to warrant trying again in the future.  After that it took pretty long for the items to be sent out the kitchen, since I doubt they were expecting this kind of crowd on opening day and they probably don't have any proper line cooks working in the back.  So by the time I finished everything and paid by bill it is 12:50pm already.  The kitchen is definitely not ready for the better than expected turnout, but hopefully with more practice they will soon get the hang of it.  As of right now, there is no POS in use, so items that are out, must be communicated to the staff taking the orders as it comes in, and if not everyone is on the same page, you end up with customers waiting for a good long time, until they either ask about the status of their order or just gives up and pay for what they have already been served. Furthermore, the kitchen and the expeditor needs to agree on how orders are placed and executed, because the time for discussing how to handle order tickets is not in the middle of service.  Food-wise, I thought it was just okay.  The best item I tried was the Spicy Beef Noodle, except I felt the beef needed to be braised longer, since not all of them were tender. There are also still a lot of things I want to try if they are actually available, so I will be back.  Menu - sadly very typical of the mom and pop operations in that the English translations of menu items are 1) misspelled, 2) poorly translated, 3) utilises questionable word choice.  If the restaurant needs someone to correct their menu, I can do it. I just hate seeing simple words like tofu, noodle, chicken spelled correctly in one part of the menu and not in others. And I also can't understand why some parts of the menu is not translated at all, like the shaved ice. It is not that hard to translate select any 3 toppings, 4 toppings, etc for X price. Parking - pretty convenient since it is in the same plaza as 168 Market.  Price - pretty reasonable for most items.  3 stars.  They also have shaved ice on the menu, but it is not available yet.

IqEVvweXVNJF0Itzrqe16g.text: So much has changed since I moved away from Vegas 2.5 years ago.  I went to Yi Mei's old location and was disappointed that they had closed, but then realized after checking Yelp that they had moved.  The new location is easily 3-4x the size of their prior location.  The food is still as solid and as authentically Taiwanese as ever.  We came for breakfast and started off with hot soy milk.  Remember, if you ask for sweet soy milk, it comes hot by default and is actually unsweetened since they expect you to sweeten it to your taste.  This is done at every Taiwanese breakfast place because sweetened soy milk being kept warm would start to burn.  The soy milk had a nice taste to it and the perfect accompaniment for what was to come.  Next came the egg pancake.  It was as good as my mom and relatives used to make.  The egg was perhaps just a tad bit oversalted, but it tasted great overall.  The tortilla component was nice and soft and chewy.  I also had a sweet rice roll, which was exactly what I expected.  They got the ratio of peanuts to cruller correct so it tasted great.  Finally, we got the "Chinese sandwich" and "Chinese donut".  Traditionally, you put the donut part inside the sandwich and then dip it into hot soy milk.  I was really impressed by the sandwich component.  It was really flaky and the sesame seeds on top added a nice flavor.  Overall, solid place for Taiwanese breakfast.  My Taiwanese parents approved.

8YeHIdZ3QgGx9QXX1fPgNg.text: There are a wide variety of traditional Taiwanese and Chinese breakfast to order from the menu. We had the egg pancake (must-have), rice roll, green onion pancake, radish pancake, pan fried dumplings, steam juicy pork buns, beef roll, Taiwanese sausage, Chinese donut, Taiwanese meatball soup, the sweet soy milk, the salted soy milk, and the boiled rice juice with peanuts. This is what homesick does to you lol. We ordered tons of these comfort food and pretty much finished them all. The taste is as authentic as you can get here in the States. Sometimes wait time could be long and service could be lousy, but this time all work out pretty good for us. Definitely the place to get the feeling of Taiwanese breakfast when you want to take a break from the buffers in Vegas!

IMnn90uVJBcMRbEugcbYQA.text: I haven't had some Taiwanese breakfast in a long time. They got the main staples: fried dough, soy milk, and egg pancakes. There are two options for soy milk, sweet or salty. If you get the sweet option, you can put as much sugar at your own risk. Taiwanese breakfast restaurants are probably the only ones I've ever seen with huge containers of sugar. Double check you aren't pouring in tons of salt by accident! I like the flavor of the salty soy milk and it even has some pieces of fried dough! Makes me feel like I'm not getting diabetes. I think the Beijing style egg pancakes have a bunch of weird things in them Just need a crepe style dough, scrambled eggs, scallions, and chili sauce on the side. The fried dough and the ( it's like a flatbread with sesame that you wrap around the fried dough) is not oily. Some of my family members thought they could be crispier, but then they would probably have to use fresh oil to fry them.

RcfQzKh0vxGePBaujL5nDQ.text: If you try this place out you might enjoy some interesting cheap-ish food, but the overall experience will be very confusing and somewhat unpleasant feeling.  We dropped by for lunch on an early Saturday afternoon. It got a little busy right after we arrived which might've contributed to the strange time we experienced there.  We ordered a few dishes to start with. We wanted some other things as well, but no one came back to take our additional orders. I tried to get someone's attention, but they were all running around like chickens with their heads cut off. Our dishes were delivered by a male server who would drop the dish off, mention what it is and then immediately run off. Wrong dishes were delivered to our table a couple of times.  Their menu is very difficult to follow if you don't already know what you want. The pictures on Yelp are very useful for figuring out what some of the dishes are.  If you don't mind not knowing what you are ordering and if you don't mind servers that have no time to talk to you about anything, then you might have an okay time here. Otherwise, the dining experience is so confusing we won't be going back.

kFW7VkDR58rBnTop2RA0rw.text: We left Vegas early to head to Death Valley... and started the morning off with a Taiwanese breakfast! Found Yi Mei on Yelp and when we got there at 10:30, it was packed! I did both breakfast and lunch items together - started off with a fan tuan (rice roll? I don't know the direct english translation) and moved on to my pai gu fan (pork + rice), which was huge. We also tried the Oyster Pancake, average... could of been better, and the green onion pancake (cong you bing), just okay. The beef noodle soups were pretty oily, so avoid those if your stomach can't handle grease. Super nice owner, actually from the bay area, and because we bought a bunch of snacks and soymilk to bring on the trip, she gave us extra things for free like a box of pineapple cakes, some sort of coffee drinks, etc. We came back a few days later and she still remembered us. Good service! It's a good break (and reasonable priced meal) from Vegas - about a 5 minute drive west of the strip -- PHOTOS: Onion Pancake: yelp.com/biz_photos/Jjjl... Pork + Rice: yelp.com/biz_photos/Jjjl... Oyster Pancake: yelp.com/biz_photos/Jjjl... Fan Tuan: yelp.com/biz_photos/Jjjl...

OnNboRVtsSAvuHnWVrk3Bw.text: I really love this place. They have traditional taiwanese food, and their food is really fantastic. Hence, it is a good place for groups during the brunch time because some cam choose to eat egg roll or rice roll and some can choose to eat noodles or rice bowl.

5tL2x2mCvGPWt9QeiPNL3w.text: Very bad experience!!! I would rate negative scores if I have that choice. The server is so rude! I took my parents here for breakfast. The server did ask us for drink at all. When I asked for water the first time, the waiter just rudely said "Wait!" without saying anything else. I waited like ten minutes, the server came by to give the other table boxes, I asked for water again. He just said, "It's too busy! Wait!!". Is that rude?!!! I asked twice with respect and smile, he just frowned and answered very impatiently replied to me. Finally, I have to go get boxes myself and checked out at the counter. The restaurant didn't even have half capacity by that time. I have no idea what the server is busying about!! The server saw me at the counter and didn't even say anything, of course didn't say sorry. I felt so sorry for my parents not getting good experience. Definitely not a recommended place for those people who wants to have at lease respected experience.

dVp1llwjZUmhCF4pNsJnQg.text: It's a Taiwanese restaurant, Cali is like that wit the bad service.  Just come for the food and forget about the service.  They don't speak/understand English that well, so don't get disappointed.  They prefer you to let them know when you're ready to order.    I'm tossed between the Noodle Pot restaurant & this place for the spicy beef stew.  The flavorings are really different.  One feels like its has more flavor (Noodle pot) but I get so thirsty afterwards.  This Yi Mei feels like it can add a little bit more seasoning but the portion size & noodles are more than the Noodle pot.  Btw, Noodle Pot only takes CASH but Yi Mei accepts credit cards.  They're both Good but I wish they taste more like Monterey Park.  I switch off between them depending which one is the closes at that moment.

avtZxeCCTbalN-z-tJdqvQ.text: This place is a hit or miss with the service but the food is always good. Tried to eat here last night at 8pm. It says they close at 9pm. We got there and all their tables were full of to go boxes for catering or something. It was so awkward. We asked if they were still open for service and the lady was like "to go?" We had said no and left coz she didn't say anything else. Anyway, I've come here a few times during breakfast hours. It's always full. They don't really speak English. I usually come with my Chinese friend and she speaks their language so it's not too hard to communicate. I did come one time with my husband and his family and a very nice girl helped us even tho she didn't speak English. so if you get passed that, the food is pretty good. I like the salted rice roll and their minced meat noodles. If you get there early enough they might still have the salted bean curd with peanuts. We've gone twice around 10am and they were out. They're always busy during breakfast hours so don't expect 5 star service, last time we just sat at a dirty table for about 20 mins before they cleared it out lol but like I said the food is good if you can get passed the service. Maybe ill try coming for lunch just to have my noodles.

5qDO0dkTcz2WkxzV_rSRLQ.text: Food is really good but have to wait a while for it come out. Everything is fresh so as long as you don't mind waiting for your food you will have a good time. Staff are friendly but don't speak much English. Go for the experience and don't be in a rush.

Beautifully crunchy on the outside, wonderfully creamy on the inside... goes well with some hot soy milk, sweetened with table sugar.  Also recommend their champion rice roll with spicy pickles. It's not too hot, just sour crunch with heat tempered with sweet pork fung.

DaEXwbEX21tyQ5TNi8eccg.text: Came here on a friend's recommendation and the food is delicious and fresh. He gave us a list of things to order, and they all sounded super delish. The server lady made us feel right at home; our conversation went something like this:  Husband: Can we get a beef noodle- Lady: No! Breakfast only!  Husband: No? You don't have the noodle soup for breakfast? Lady: No! No noodle until 9:00. Breakfast only!  Husband: Okaaaay...then can we get the breakfast special?  Lady: No! No breakfast special!  Husband: ....egg omelette?  Lady: What?! What number? This one? (Pointing vigorously at the menu) Husband: uh, yeah. And the leek pancake, please. Lady: What?! Husband: (pointing at the menu) this one. Lady: ok. Anything else? Husband: the sweet soy drink, please. Lady: What?!  ...you get the idea. The service was...authentic. I felt right at home :)  The food was great. Flavorful and fresh. We also ordered the pan fried pork pot stickers and a beef sandwich (which was a lot of food, btw...don't order that much unless you are planning to save some for later). Everything was great.

Fnbegl-yZkDON5vnKJtXpQ.text: Got the XLB, potstickers, pork bun, chive pancakes, and soy milk. Only the XLB and the potstickers were alright, the rest just didn't suit me and my family's tastes. The soy milk was especially watered down.

jZ0kpGmPmBxhG4bAQeXggw.text: Very good for brunch. Both the quality and quantity are excellent and it is not pricy at all.

IIeV0i78Lh1dYxVb4fa1Kw.text: Food is very delicious and authentic. However, like other reviewers mentioned, service is non existent here. We had the salty rice roll and egg pancake with Chinese donut, both are great. If the wait time isn't so long and service better, we'll definitely come back. As is, we'll have to think about it.

gk02jfT6-ZvVLFyThAG_Fg.text: Get your $$ worth here! Big portions!! Homemade noodles were chewy just the way we like it. Chinese donuts were on steroids! Beef noodle soup great tasting spice to it with a little kick. Pork chops were light, crispy & fried perfectly. XLB dumplings didn't have any soup/broth in it but the filling was still flavorful. Even though there was a language barrier we still had great service here.

cjqDKKaZ7Ky5VnNXPeU0MQ.text: Pretty good Taiwanese food. We ordered a bunch of dishes to share- taiwanese oxtail noodle soup, beef rolls, pancake, rice roll, pork and rice, and soup dumplings. Be prepared for some spiciness because the oxtail noodle soup was spicy. It was a little pricey compared to the Taiwanese deli here in California. I thought the soup dumplings were just okay... not enough soup in them and kind of dried out.

F0ZB1DjfyKjaAxgW5run-w.text: Owner/chef Borman Yung is a charming, incandescent, talented cook and businesswoman.  I met her a few weeks ago when I popped my head in to see what Yi Mei was all about...she immediately began to ply me with deliciousness (but truth be told, I'd just had a huge lunch at China Mama) so I promised her I'd return.  So when I was invited to lunch today by two of my favorite students and adventurous eaters, I knew they'd love exploring Yi Mei with me...and we had a blast.  First, I reviewed what previous reviewers have said on yelp - cross referencing it with the menu she gave me and John Curtas' thoughts...then I dug in and made a list of the dishes that I knew we should try on our first pass -- and it was an amazing first visit...  Spicy Beef Noodle soup was terrific...well balanced delicious - not that spicy...but really good... and the noodles...oy.  Scallion Pancake...textbook  Beef roll...honestly this was my least favorite - but the pickled cucumber and and the kimchee with it were so good, I didn't care.  Sticky Rice Roll with shredded pork...think sweet, fuzzy, crispy, umami chewiness...awesome.  totally the first time I've ever had anything like this before and I loved it.    Sesame Sauced Wide Noodles that were divine...rich, garlicky, warm, with scallions.  again - the noodles were perfectly cooked - so wonderful.    XLB that were perfectly sized...finally, I didn't feel like I was going to choke because I had too much in my mouth - these were heavenly. The broth inside wasn't scalding - but I've had them enough now to know how to eat them - with great respect...  Potstickers - no, not redundant, completely different in technique - and with the addition of leeks to the minced pork, these, too, were just perfect.  Two of us ordered chrysanthemum teas - another ordered winter melon juice which was like drinking raisin-honey water...completely surprising and delicious.  So, as table after table of Chinese left, giving us thumbs up, we realized we'd clearly ordered and eaten impressively...We just couldn't stop....  That's when we met Borman...I kept looking for the darling woman I'd met the first time - but she wasn't there... (because she was cooking...)  She came out to see how we liked everything - and I smiled... she said her 80 year old mother had taken the day off... so she was in the kitchen.  We raved to her - so with that she picked out her two favorite desserts and cups of freshly squeezed soy milk and presented them to us, on her.   I didn't think I could eat another bite - but naturally, we soldiered on through what I thought would be sickeningly sweet...I was wrong... everything was subtle, interesting, unlike anything I'd had before - although somewhat recognizable.  From the sun cookie with the chinese symbol on top. to the sweet fried bread, to creamy, but refreshingly wonderful...I was hooked.  She told us about her breakfast.    We talked about her children - which is why she came to America - for their education...one's a doctor in Ohio, the other also a doctor with an MBA... She left behind a producing career in radio in Taiwan to support them here...and hasn't looked back... Single now, she's funny and contagiously happy, a wonderful story teller and completely passionate about doing things right.    I never knew how soy milk was made - she gave us a detailed lesson - and probably would have given us a demo, had we asked...I'll have to remember to do that next time.    As we left, she asked me how many folks I worked with, and sent me back to the office with three boxes of pineapple cakes for them - and plenty of menus - and an offer to do anything to help whenever I might need it... : )   She also mentioned proudly her Yelp event...and how much she adores Misti and her husband...how she met them, and raved about his musical talent and regaled us with stories of them and Kevin Costner... ask her!     This is one of the reasons I've really grown to love Las Vegas - the possibility of finding special treasures like this - Yi Mei and Borman - one and the same - inextricably intertwined, families doing what they love - and loving us in the process...  Go, eat.    Open 7 days, 7am - 9pm.

iG-1dubAWV1zmeQfHCdd2Q.text: Growing up on Taiwanese breakfast, I desperately wanted to find authentic Taiwanese breakfast in Vegas. I found Yi Mei Champion and I have been making them a routine stop for breakfast in my Vegas visits. Service is terrible but their food is great. Their turn around time from ordering can be better. I think they are just short staffed.  I recommend getting their salty rice rolls. A staple in Taiwanese street food, it's a roll of rice with fried air bread, shredded pork and pickled cabbage inside. It's cheap, tasty and filling. Their soy milk is also really good here. I didn't think much of their scallion pancakes or dumplings. They were average. Overall, their breakfast items are lighter than American breakfast and much cheaper.

7yskOMwPrk5S_YZuIb4zIA.text: Value 2* cheap prices but one of us got food poisoning Location 4* easy to find off the strip Cleanliness 1* the establishment is a hole in the wall, with old table cloths and not so clean open utensils.  one out of our party of four got GI distress after eating here. Variety 4.5* nice menu selection Food taste 3* the dishes we tried tasted ok, not outstanding.  Providing a relief from Americana style breakfasts in Vegas, this small homey restaurant offers dishes unique to the usual strip fare.   The Chinese fried dough crullers were nice and crunchy, not too oily. The porridge was well made and standard. The green onion pancakes were a bit thick but pretty crunchy and not too oily. The soup dumplings, which was what brought us here, however, were disappointing; there wasn't enough soup, the dumpling skin was somewhat brittle and uneven. The pork filling lacked seasoning though the texture was good.   Though this place falls short of food you would get in coastal metropolitan chinatowns, it's a great food option if you're looking for a different meal at low prices, but beware, you may get sick eating here.

gIcWcqPS5j7gnSAPVIEKFw.text: Another mediocre forgettable dining experience in Chinatown, Las Vegas  Their 3-cup chicken dish is very bland. There is no garlic, ginger and Thai basil as authentic Taiwanese recipe. Their fish fillet is a disaster as it's just like they got precooked breaded fish fillets from Walmart then deep fried them to serve you. Bland, dried, tasteless... Service is not so good. We are the only 2nd table in the restaurant and the lady brought us food then disappeared without even bringing any water. We have to ask when we saw her after finishing more than half of our meal.  They turn on the TV so loud with either Chinese news or some kind of Chinese drama.  The ambience is not good as there are plenty of empty carton boxes in the corner, stacks of drinks/water bottles in the middle of the room.   Definitely not return.

eow_DjPxCsI1ieNN5W9quQ.text: Decent Taiwanese breakfast food, but I suppose I should be grateful that it even exists. Stinky tofu could have been much more pungent, and while the beef in the beef rolls were good, the wrapping was quite lacklustre. Oyster pancake okay at best. Prices were reasonable and despite the mediocrity, everything was authentically done.

FQvGubJZU6PStRdiG9DSAw.text: This is the worst Taiwanese breakfast/lunch place I have ever had, in the USA, Taiwan and Canada. I can't believe they are still in business. Nothing we ordered was fresh. Your classic Chinese donut and baked sandwich was definitely not made this morning. It was chewy, like in a stale way. The soy bean drink has a burnt and gritty taste, which some people may like but I totally didn't. The egg pancake was over cooked, i could make a better one myself at home with frozen pancake you buy at the store and add an egg. The stuffed rice roll was the only edible thing out of the 6 items we ordered.  Definitely, never coming back again.

Y1Vni4Kr_iT-apKObT4INg.text: My friend highly recommended this Taiwanese breakfast spot in Vegas when I told him I was going, so the 4 of us decided to order delivery via DoorDash on a recent trip to Vegas.  We may have gone a little bit too crazy on the ordering, with a whopping 13 items in the cart for just for 4 people. We probably ordered enough for at least 7 people, but that just meant we had plenty of leftovers for the next day!  I didn't eat all of this, but here is what we ordered. Prices are very reasonable too; nothing was over $5.  1. Sweet Soybean Milk with Peanuts ($2.25) 5. Salted Bean Curd with Peanuts ($3.99) 7. Chinese Donut ($2.25) 8. Egg Cake with Chinese Donut ($4.99) 14. Salted Rice Roll ($3.50) 15. Yi Mei Rice Roll with Mustard Green ($3.95) 16. Champion Rice Roll with Spicy Pickled Vegetable ($4.75) 17. Egg Pancake ($3.99) 20. Green Onion Pancake with Egg ($4.99) 22. Radish Pancake with Egg ($4.99) 24. Taiwan Style Meat Ball ($4.99)  My favorites were the egg pancake and the radish pancake with egg. The egg pancake was extremely soft, and the radish pancake had a lot of flavor. Both were a tiny bit on the bland side, but the radish pancake came with a delicious soy sauce/ginger sauce that we dipped everything in.  One member of our group was vegetarian, so I appreciated that the radish pancake didn't seem to have any dried sausage in it like it normally does. The one thing I would change is that I would order some items with eggs but not everything. We were pretty egg'd out by the end of the meal.  I didn't eat any of the salted rice rolls since they all came with dried pork floss inside and I'm not a fan of that, but that was a hit with my other friends.

Photo of Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ewQB8pXxQRrOhMaxUG0x4w.text: I have never had authentic Taiwanese food in Vegas until this year. So I tried their sweet soybean milk, their radish pancake, egg pancake, Chinese donut, corn porridge, pork chop rice and spicy tendon noodle. Their sweet soybean milk really stands out as the pulp from the soybeans create an interesting but fresh aftertaste. Also their radish pancake taste better than a regular radish pancake at a dim sum place because it's fried better with more flavor. The egg pancake wasn't as good as advertised, when I got it it was cold. The Chinese donut was comparable to any other Dim sum place. The corn porridge was tasteless (I don't know if that's what it supposed to taste like). The pork chop rice plate had plenty of quantity and variety but taste wise not as good as some of the Vietnamese rice plates. And for the spicy beef tendon noodle soup, I don't think 3 tendons is enough. Overall, I would come back for quick grab or as an alternative to dim sum. But their quality can be improved.

XmyXr9bGZm34ZmJkOnCN3Q.text: The food was pretty good but the service was bad. It took forever to get someone's attention and to even get waters for the table. We ordered a bunch of their breakfast items, which were pretty standard e.g. egg pancake, Chinese donut (you tiao), rice roll (fan tuan), minced pork over rice, scallion pancake, sweet soybean milk, etc. Everything was okay but nothing stood out. In the end we paid about $12/pp which was okay but not that cheap for mostly carbs.

WL0NCEbgUvwoB6ah_gWThA.text: Confession: I have actually never had full on Taiwanese breakfast before. I'm Cantonese, used to dim sum. So when I came to Yi Mei, I was thoroughly impressed by the breakfast options, even if it's a lot of carb on carb action.  They have a vast menu and serve most of the items there pretty early in the day. Portions are also plentiful.  Here's everything in order of what we liked: 1. Chinese Donut Egg cake - basically its an omelet stuffed with the chinese donut. Crisp and crunchy, juxtaposed by egg. Good way to start the day. 2. Simmered beef flank, tendon and tofu - its cold cuts basically with a chili sauce. I think I particularly liked it because it had some deeper flavors that countered all the carbs we ordered, but its cool, crunchy, chewy and tender depending on what you pick up with the chopsticks. Good to take in between bites. 3. Beef roll - think of the beef above rolled in a pancake. Also comes with smashed cucumbers and kimchi, which is also appreciated for its refreshing palate cleansing power. 3. Fresh soymilk - good for dipping the chinese donut but also it is just sweet enough with a decent bit of grit. 4. Green Onion Pancake (w/egg) - we got both with and without egg, but with egg is better. It's a bit dense, not as layered as I would like my green onion pancake to be, but with the egg, the texture contrast again helps. 5. Tea eggs - they're good, but not particularly strong flavored. Nice patterning though on the egg. 6. Steamed vegetable buns - fluffy and chock full of filling  All in all, if you want a good breakfast and just eating by yourself, I would recommend the soy milk with just the chinese donut (with or without the egg). They fry it well and it works with everything!

SzFlJuaGB34WLw9ZkWd_Cw.text: Spicy tendon noodle soup, XLB, meatball, and that flaky cookie/pastry were all quite satisfactory. I'll be adding this to the rotation when I'm in Vegas. They have more room to accommodate large groups vs. Shang Artisan Noodle or Noodle Pot. The texture of the noodle was al dente and tasted handcut...I will gladly return when I'm hungover and in need of soup!

thKqAWak088sS6LKTJpjyg.text: We got salty fan tuan, xiao long bao, green onion pancake, Chinese fried donut wrapped with egg and soy milk. Food was good, besides the burnt green onion pancake. Very authentic Taiwanese breakfast! It's very very cheap too! Typical Chinese restaurant service but I don't mind it.

ew9fkdd-odxNeTq3VHGIbQ.text: Authentic! The rating may be deceiving from the peeps who aint used to authenic Taiwanese food.

23YyVQVHuAMLQqKxstc9TQ.text: Came here on Christmas and the worst service I've had in a long time (they probably aren't this busy the rest of the year). They skipped us in line. Served another table before us and they were eating before we placed our order. Waited 20 minutes after we sat (I actually timed this) for them to take our order (actually we had to go up to the waiter and give them our order).   Unfortunately the food is delicious so can be worth the hassle if you and your Asian parents aren't in a rush and are craving Taiwanese food. We got all breakfast food and it came quickly after we ordered. Not the best I've had but very good. The radish pancake was surprisingly good. The baked beef sandwich had good beef but was dry. Dipping it into the salted soybean milk helped. The temple meatball skin was thin but solid flavor.   They include tip on the bill so that doesn't really incentivize good service.

_z076CwVrmiafRVMG807dA.text: On our way home from AZ, we stopped by here in Vegas for some lunch grub. If you're able to get there before the crazy lunch hour then you're golden because this place was PACKED when we got there.  First off, you know you "made" it to the right delicious place when most of the workers there don't speak much English, service is a little subpar, but the food is goshdarn delicious.  We ordered the salty rice roll, which is pretty delicious even though it's such a very simple dish. But hey- sometimes the simpler the better! Their soup dumplings are also pretty delicious, but the wrapping is somewhat a bit too thin so some of the dumplings leaked the delicious juice right as you picked it up from the tin.  Our favorite dish was the daikon with egg. So delicious! I highly recommend this one, and it's great for sharing too.   Overall, the food here is really good. Don't expect 5 star service, but your tummy will be happy. Credit cards accepted, plenty of parking.

ztuanwRRjabuXx2S6d_omw.text: I dont know why we can't have nice things like this in D.C.  Don't stand in a ridiculous line to pay enormous sums of money for dim sum marginally better than reheating frozen stuff bought at the grocery store.   come here for a street vendor style breakfast.  spent less than $10 and had plenty of leftovers.   practically as fast as a street vendor too.  just in and out with no formalities, frills, or shenanigans.    I didn't try any real dishes, just grabbed a some baos, pancakes and what not.  really hit the spot.  everything seemed legitimate and  fresh

ywCY7riN_IJD2NAyjjxuPw.text: I wish there were more places offering Chinese breakfast here in Vegas. Not dim sum type breakfast, but the street vendor type that just tastes so comforting. Taiwanese breakfast doesn't quite satisfy this craving but it does hold its own merits of buns, pancakes, and rice rolls galore. I brought my grandparents here for breakfast and we ordered a variety of items to share  The egg pancake was recommended to us as a savory selection for my diabetic gramps and it was our favorite. Just a soft fluffy omelette cooked onto a thin pancake. So simple and delicious. The you tiao was crisp and the soy milk was hot and fresh. Pro tip- dip a piece in the soy milk just like you'd dunk an Oreo. Can't go wrong with that classic combo, it's a match made in heaven!  Everything else was good. Maybe not great, but still good. Tastes just about the same as it did years ago at their old location next to 168 Market. Cheap prices for a ton of food that's all served up real fast. I love how the owner helped package our leftovers individually in baggies. Not only does it help the environment as less boxes are used, it also prevents food from touching and provides easy utensil free eating

J8uQpnsD70p4tiztR06oxw.text: Visiting a friend in Henderson and wanted to try a local Taiwanese joint.    The good:  The warm Sesame Noodles were amazing!  This used to be one of my favorite dishes in Taiwan, and very rarely have I found a place that will give you a bowl with a heaping of sesame paste/sauce.  Usually it is a very tiny spoonful, or at least that's how it is in LA.  The noodles were warm, soft and chewy, and the cucumbers added some texture to it.  For me, it is worth coming back.  The waitress says they make their own sesame paste.  I have ordered it at restaurants in LA before, and it was literally just a package they bought from the local 99 ranch grocery store.  Tip:  throw in some of the chili oil and soy sauce to increase the flavor.    Also, the green onion pancake with egg was great!  I was eating with a friend that doesn't usually eat Taiwanese food, and this was his favorite thing.  Warm, crunchy, salty, and savory; it's a great  snack, but I can't verify if it is homemade.  Honestly, green onion pancake is pretty difficult to mess up, and i have rarely had a bad one.  The bad:  The corn porridge.  I can't verify how authentic it is, but whatever it is, I won't be ordering it again.  Pretty much just water and like cornmeal.  Super thin, and without any flavor at all.  Put in some sauces to add flavor, still didn't really like it.  Save your money.    The OK:  The salty fan tuan.  I can't remember what it translated to in English, but it is like a burrito with the outside layer being made of hardened rice.  Inside, there is a long chinese donut (you tiao) and meat floss.  That is just ok and very standard for the places I have ordered from before.  No place in the US comes close to fan tuan in china with crispy pork, crispy chinese donut in the center and pickled vegetables inside.  The search continues to find a good one.    Final Verdict:  I would return for the noodles and green onion pancake, would avoid the others and possibly try some new things.

Fyu-YxpDax6q24O8S4jaBA.text: This place was highly recommended for legit Taiwanese food.  I am filipino-chinese and am not very familiar with Taiwanese food so I ordered an assortment of things to share.  Soup dumplings, take a few minutes to prepare,  they were very good.  We ordered a beef noodle soup, a shrimp omelet (had a gravy on top with a hint of cinnamon?), pork/chives dumplings (nothing special and tasted like any frozen dumpling from an asian grocery store), beef pancake wrap, and tea eggs.   They serve breakfast and open at 7 am.  We landed in Vegas, and went for a late lunch on a Saturday before we headed to Zion NP.  It wasnt crowded and we were seated quickly.  I can see this place being very crowded during peak wknd lunch hrs.   They have a takeout area too.  Underwhelming experience.  But willing to try again with a Taiwanese friend.

mLnLe0YD8-Z6zgKIlxjZ5g.text: The place is ok. I don't know of another place that serves the traditional Taiwanese breakfast items. The restaurant is extremely cluttered and the service is typical Chinese efficient but on the short side(could be thought of as rude). Didn't find anything bad tasting but definitely nothing was great. We had Chinese donuts, salted soy milk, sweet rice wrapped donut with pork Sung, onion pancake, and another dough item I have no clue how to describe in English. The onion pancake was too thick and onions but the other items were fine.

yHePJz9au_V_LvFJ3Kcovg.text: Authentic Taiwanese place where the food is legit, and my mom and her friends love to come here often when in Vegas.  Their strong suit is Taiwanese/Chinese brunch dishes, and it's very affordably priced (for Vegas) with good portions.    I really liked the pork and chive dumplings (fresh and juicy, perfect) and pan-fried scallion pancake (definitely one of the better ones I've had). Service at this unassuming place is friendly too.

FnTv4MsGOVVA54vgMDsxaw.text: Honestly, this place was great! As I entered Yi Mei Champion Taiwan Deli, it was crowded so I assumed it was good. When we got seated we waited for about 20 minutes before the waiter got to us. When we ordered food, the waiter cut us off and went to the kitchen. Me and my friends were not finished yet. People got their food before us and my friends got their Waters before I did. Later our food came. It was DELICIOUS but we still had to order the rest of the order that we didn't get to tell the waiter. 5 minutes later he got to us. The food was great (again). After we were done we paid and tipped them and then were on our way back to our hotel. Personally it was good but the service was just a tiny bit slow. Thank you!

sn8_MDS5FeJtKvm2YZrYrA.text: Came here for a quick breakfast before a day of skiing, and it was great that this place is open at 7am! (So that we could make it to the slopes by 9) Service was quick and the menu was pretty extensive.  We had an assortment of the standard Chinese breakfast fare (although there were a few menu items that were unavailable). The you tiao were alright, but I really liked their green onion pancake! Overall a great place to grab some authentic Chinese breakfast!

SBpSMnUd1A_mE0je5IiHhw.text: Service could be slow. But breakfast is really authentic and price is unbelievably good. I actually always buy a bunch of bao-zi to go for my weekday breakfast.  Some of my favourite items include the tea flavored eggs, chive pancake and of course the salted soymilk!  The marinated flavored items are also great! duck tongues, duck necks and duck gizzards available!

M8mL1MmQhVLDXkNPzWFIrQ.text: One of my favorite Chinese restaurants!! I live in New York, but go to Vegas every year or so and this is my first stop! The owners are so sweet and nice to me, and remember me and my family everytime we go. The food reminds me of Taiwan, and there's definitely no Chinese food in New York like this. I'm from LA near monterey park and this is still my favorite spot!

cAyuN2DnvzsE4hVtVOn1qA.text: Dem Steam Buns!  Ambiance: Hole in the wall. (Hope you can speak Mandarin Chinese) Service: Don't expect much Food Quality: I only come here to buy Steam Buns but they are 10/10 Price: Economic  I am an avid fan of this place for the quality of their steam buns. On a normal day I would swing by and purchase 2 dozen buns, pop them in the freezer and when I'm ready pop it in a steamer or microwave (if it's thawed) and it's just as good as day 1.

I wasn't expecting good authentic Taiwanese food in Las Vegas, but this place is decent enough to satiate the Taiwanese cravings!

swrt65sp4Ji89viqdcl2pQ.text: Horrible, horrible service (more like non-existent); mediocre food; more expensive than places that serve a similar menu... Need I say more?   Have been here more than once because of one reason or the other, and in the end, it just really wasn't worth it. And to top it off, you gotta get your own water! Such a weird establishment...

ZTcqCxm76CEHVBqa8Df2_Q.text: Its the infamous Champion Deli! Legit Taiwanese food in Vegas!  Alot is good, the owner is nice... Every time i come here, I over order. Its worth it :)

CNthsfdR3XK0AHPhVdkRew.text: Four of us from the SF/LA area tried the Taiwanese breakfast at this hole-in-the-wall.  Recommend:  Spicy beef soup with tendon, Taiwan sweet spicy cabbage, tendon brisket tofu, beef sandwich.  Okay:  Green onion pancake with egg, salty rice roll (fan tuan), pot stickers.  Not so great:  Sweet soy milk (not at all sweet), Chinese donut (not crispy).

vSB6vrgaqwLT_bcD-jR2Xg.text: Horrible. Wasn't greeted or acknowledged for the longest time till we decided to speak up and tell them we're ready. One of the worst Chinese restaurant experiences and I've been eating out in NYC and San Diego. Save your money and don't come here! They moved to a new location so they can do the big tour group business. We went there at 10:30am and was restricted to maybe 5 things on the menu. All their woks and cooking utensils were all being used for them to cook up food for the bus tours. Ridiculous. If we wanted anything outside of the maybe 5 items available it would be a 20 minute wait! Just shitty! We left without paying an extra dime cause thee people sure didn't deserve it! Ten people hustling and bustling and no one gave us an ounce of attention! Shitty Vegas service!! Not exactly cheap either! We ordered one sweet soybean drink and one salty one and two meat with veggie bun and it came out to $11! Total ripoff!

KiPHWz502BCq6zYTvv_OYQ.text: This review is only for the rice balls (glutinous rice wrapped with shredded pork, fried dough, picked vegetables) - generous size, plenty of fillings, satisfied my cravings for rice ball.  Will return when in the area.

4s39S0CWdaZBv5p1HUnGLQ.text: The food tasted ok. I've ordered the spicy beef noodle and the oyster pancake, wasn't impressed with neither. I also found a HAIR in my noodle, gross.  Also, if you want water, you have to get it yourself in the water station, wtf??? Should I also go into the kitchen and get the food myself???
